editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE Blinde Guide, or the Doting Doctor.

CompoÅ¿ed by way of Reply to a late tediouÅ¿ly trifling Pamphlet, Entituled, The Youngling Elder, &c. written by John Goodwin, and containing little or nothing in it, but what plainly Å¿peaketh the Author thereof to lie under the double unhappineÅ¿Å¿e of Seducers, To be Deceiving And Deceived.
This reply indifferently Å¿erving for the future direction of the Seducer himÅ¿elfe, and alÅ¿o of thoÅ¿e his miÅ¿-led followers, who with him are turned enemies to the Word and grace of God.

The authority of which Word, and the efficacie of which grace are in this following TreatiÅ¿e, Å¿uccinctly, yet Å¿atisfactorily vindicated from the deplorably weake, and erroneous Cavills of the Å¿aid John Goodwin in his late Pamphlet.
By William Jenkyn, MiniÅ¿ter of the Word of God at ChriÅ¿t-Church in LONDON.

q.p: Evill men and Å¿educers Å¿hall wax worÅ¿e and worÅ¿e, deceiving, and being deceived.
The foole rageth and is confident.
Raging waves of the Å¿ea foming out their owne Å¿hame.
Contra Mennonem. Hoc Å¿ane video, nihil hoc aÅ¿ino poÅ¿Å¿e fingi Å¿uperbius.

div.p: Printed at London by M. B. for ChriÅ¿topher Meridith, and are to be Å¿old at his Shop at the Å¿igne of the Crane in Pauls Church-yard.

div.head: To the ChriÅ¿tian READER.
div.p:
WEre not my deÅ¿ire to Å¿erve thy Soul, greater than my hope to recover my AdverÅ¿ary, and were I not more apprehenÅ¿ive of the greatneÅ¿Å¿e of thy danger, than the goodneÅ¿Å¿e of his diÅ¿poÅ¿ition, I Å¿hould not Å¿pend my precious houres in a Å¿econd engagement againÅ¿t his Errours; my contention is greater that thou Å¿houldeÅ¿t not fall to be like him, than that he Å¿hould riÅ¿e to be unlike himÅ¿elfe. He who wrote his laÅ¿t Pamphlet only to repreÅ¿ent me unworthy to contend with
him, will hardly write his next to confeÅ¿Å¿e that truth by me hath conquered him. It's not conÅ¿iÅ¿tent with his honour, who in his laÅ¿t boaÅ¿ted, that he had laid the attempts of all his adverÅ¿aries in the duÅ¿t, Ep. to the Reader, To. Eld. p. 3. and that Presbytery lay bleeding at the feet of his Writings, in his next to lay himÅ¿elfe in the duÅ¿t, and to acknowledge that his HereÅ¿ies lye bleeding at the foot of a Yongling; Å¿o that Å¿hould he be convinced of the duty, (as poÅ¿Å¿ibly he may) he would be afraid of the Å¿hame of a recantation. Its more his Å¿in than my unhappineÅ¿Å¿e (though both) that by confuting his errours I occaÅ¿ion him Å¿till to vent them; but never did I meet with wretched opinions Å¿o wrathfully aÅ¿Å¿erted, and Å¿o weakly maintained. His Writings have more of Tongue than matter,
ã€ˆ in non-Latin alphabet ã€‰ NiÅ¿Å¿en de Tri. and yet more of Teeth than either; with the weapon of the Tooth (like the Hereticks of old) he conquers, even after he is overcome with Arguments.

Certainly while MaÅ¿ter Goodwin wrote his late Booke he was under a quotidian fit of Frenzie, and all that time was an interregnum of his reaÅ¿on, his Pen being onely dipt in paÅ¿Å¿ion. His Pamphlet conÅ¿iÅ¿ts of Å¿uch unmanlike
Å¿coldings, that he hath rendred himÅ¿elfe the Å¿hame of his, Party, and the Å¿corne of his OppoÅ¿ites; the only product of his reproaches, being a confirmation of the report of his being badly nurtur'd formerly, and worÅ¿e natur'd Å¿till; Æ²nhappy man! who Å¿tumbleth in the darke, and Å¿tormeth againÅ¿t the light, and who alwaies endureth that leaÅ¿t which he wanteth moÅ¿t. The weakneÅ¿Å¿e of Flatterers hath Å¿o abus'd him into love of himÅ¿elfe, and the Å¿trength of intereÅ¿t into the love of Errour, that he cannot abide either plaine-dealing, or Å¿ound doctrine. The palpable weakneÅ¿Å¿e of his late performance in his Youngl. Eld. Ep. to Reader, P. ult. extorted from him this acknowledgement, that he wrote not his Booke to refute me, and had not his LordÅ¿hip Å¿ilenced his ConÅ¿cience, it would have added, but to revile me; Yo. Eld. p. 1. I confeÅ¿Å¿e he words it more gently, telling me, that the taske to which he was confin'd in his Writing, was to Å¿hew me more of my Å¿elfe (nothing of him Å¿elfe) and in purÅ¿uance of this mercifull deÅ¿igne, he puts his whole Booke under a quaternion of topicks, 1. My defect of ConÅ¿cience. 2. Of ClerkÅ¿hip. 3. Of apprehenÅ¿ion. 4. Of ingenuity (forgetting in the meane time
one little defect which runs through the veines of all his foure parts, viz. while he Å¿o rudely handles my name, Å¿carce to touch the matter of my Booke) unto which foure defects he reduceth whatÅ¿oever malice or falÅ¿hood can invent. againÅ¿t me; though the proÅ¿ecution of them all be a continued tranÅ¿greÅ¿Å¿ion of the Lawes of Art and honeÅ¿ty, nay, not only of method, but even at once of common modeÅ¿ty; Å¿o that I know not in this world, the thins that are Å¿o contemptible, as MaÅ¿ter Goodwins Å¿currilities;
ã€ˆ in non-Latin alphabet ã€‰ . BaÅ¿il. De ira. for my part, I much more regard that excellent advice of BaÅ¿il, Neither be proud of thy praiÅ¿es, nor impatient at thy reproaches, when neither are due unto thee.

I confeÅ¿Å¿e, I delight not to Å¿ee him in thoÅ¿e diÅ¿tempers, for which I pitty him; I never intended to drive him into a Frenzie, and yet neither am I willing that he Å¿hould drive me into a PalÅ¿ie; idle Å¿ilence is a Å¿inne as well as idle Å¿peaking: his Contumelies can be no plea for my CowardiÅ¿e; where Å¿inne is impudent, reproofe muÅ¿t not be baÅ¿hfull. If errours Å¿eeke no corners, Å¿hould truth doe Å¿o? How happy were we if we could leave all our Å¿tings in the Å¿ides of Errour and
ProphaneÅ¿Å¿e! if in their blood all our hatreds might be dround! I have ever thought, that peace with that with which we Å¿hould contend, is the grand cauÅ¿e of contention with them with whom we Å¿hould be at peace. Its juÅ¿t that they who will not knwon Errour Å¿o as to hate it, Å¿hould not know Truth Å¿o as to find it, How incongruous is it to Å¿hun that man, upon whom (as thou thinkeÅ¿t) thou eÅ¿pyeÅ¿t a Wart, and to take him into thy boÅ¿ome upon whom thou knoweÅ¿t there is a Plague-Å¿ore? Errours in DiÅ¿cipline doe but Å¿cratch the face of Religion; theÅ¿e in Doctrine Å¿tab it to the heart. To. Eld. p. 20. p. 47. p. 66 When the whole written Word is at once Å¿truck off from being the ground of faith, and whatever is in and about the Scriptures denyed to be the foundation of Religion, unleÅ¿Å¿e the CounÅ¿els contained in them. When it Å¿hall be aÅ¿Å¿erted, that naturall men want no power of making themÅ¿elves able to beleeve, and that notwithÅ¿tanding all the power of converting grace, there's a liberty in the will to defeat and fruÅ¿trate converÅ¿ion; In a word, when Sectaries Å¿trike at the faith, both which and with which we beleeve,Jude ver. 3. its our duty (if ever) to contend for this
faith once delivered to the Saints; In my preÅ¿ent endeavours about which worke, if thou embraceÅ¿t what thou findeÅ¿t of God, I Å¿hall not only be willing that thou Å¿houldÅ¿t reject, and deÅ¿irous that thou wouldÅ¿t remit whatever thou findeÅ¿t of man, but Å¿hall alÅ¿o ever remaine thankfull to God, and Reader,

dateline.hi: From my Study at ChriÅ¿t-Church, London,

closer.signed: A friend to thy-Soule. William Jenkyn.

div.head: Chap. 1.

argument.p: Directed more particularly to the reverend and learned Å¿ubÅ¿cribers of the late teÅ¿timony to the truth with-in the Province of London. Shewing the Å¿enÅ¿eleÅ¿Å¿e raylings, the groÅ¿Å¿e untruths, the Å¿hameleÅ¿Å¿e boaÅ¿tings; expreÅ¿Å¿ed by MaÅ¿ter Goodwin in his PaÅ¿quill called, The youngling Elder, With a recitall of Å¿undry weake and erroneous paÅ¿Å¿ages contained therein.

div.p:
THe reproached in Mr. Goodwins Pamphlets, have more need to be humble under their glory, than to be patient under their diÅ¿grace; no Å¿criblings are Å¿o Å¿currilous, and no Å¿currilities are Å¿o honourable, as are thoÅ¿e which drop from his pen. 'Tis rare to meet with that ChriÅ¿tian, who doth not more than conjecture that there is much worth in every thing againÅ¿t which he expreÅ¿Å¿eth much wrath. His AntagoniÅ¿ts never could do him good with their will â€¢ , but he hath ever done them good
againÅ¿t his will. By writing againÅ¿t his errours they could never make him better, but be hath ever by rayling againÅ¿t the truth and them, made both to be better beloved. I Å¿uppoÅ¿e MaÅ¿ter Goodwin rather noteth than liketh that abundant eÅ¿timation which your teÅ¿timony findeth with the faithfull. The Å¿tones that this Shime â€¢
hath caÅ¿t againÅ¿t it, God hath turned into pearÅ¿es, and made of them a Crown of honour for it. Your teÅ¿timony oppoÅ¿ed errour, and God hath made it to vanquiÅ¿h infamy. He who directed you to make it uÅ¿efull, hath himÅ¿elf made it accepted.

God hath cauÅ¿ed your teÅ¿timony like the Å¿un to riÅ¿e on the evill and on the good, and rather than it Å¿hould not refreÅ¿h them that did deÅ¿ire it, to diffuÅ¿e its beams on them that did not deÅ¿erve it. It hath Å¿hined upon the unÅ¿avoury dunghill as well as the pleaÅ¿ant garden, the cloÅ¿e and noyÅ¿ome alley as well as the Å¿weet and open Country. No wonder then if its Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿e have been as various as its objects. When its welcome warmth viÅ¿ited the Countries, WarwickÅ¿hire, EÅ¿Å¿ex, Norfolk, DevonÅ¿hire, YorkÅ¿hire, NorthamptonÅ¿hire, LancaÅ¿hire, WiltÅ¿hire, SomerÅ¿etÅ¿hire. how Å¿weetly fragrant was the Å¿avour which inÅ¿tantly they breathed forth? Who hath not gratefully reÅ¿ented the pleaÅ¿ant odours of zeale and learning Å¿cattered through the Kingdome by the MiniÅ¿ters of Å¿undry Counties, in the many atteÅ¿tations to, and approbations of your teÅ¿timony? Some of us have Å¿eene the letters of the learned Spanhemius highly approving of it, as an eminent expreÅ¿Å¿ion of your faithfulneÅ¿Å¿e to ChriÅ¿t and his truth. A Declaration and exhortation, pag. 34. The many teÅ¿timonies which the truth and cauÅ¿e of ChriÅ¿t, the Covenant, and Presbyte
â€¢ iall Government, have lately received from that cloud of witneÅ¿Å¿es of the MiniÅ¿try in leverall Counties of England, after the example of the worthy MiniÅ¿try of the City of London, againÅ¿t the errours of Independency, AnabaptiÅ¿me, &c. are unto us matter of great praiÅ¿e and hearty thankÅ¿giving. And who obÅ¿erveth not the frequent and reÅ¿pectfull mention that the famous and faithfull Generall AÅ¿Å¿embly of the Church of Scotland maketh of your teÅ¿timony, in their Declarations of moÅ¿t publique concernment. TheÅ¿e indeed were the breathings of the more Å¿weet and open places, when warmed with the zeale of your witneÅ¿Å¿ing to the truth. But who can expect the like from the unÅ¿avoury dunghill, or the noyÅ¿om alley, though joyntly enjoying the Å¿ame bounty from the beams of your teÅ¿timony with the other?

ThoÅ¿e Å¿tinking exhalations, thoÅ¿e muddy Å¿treames, I meane the
Å¿uming and fooliÅ¿h pamphlets ariÅ¿ing againÅ¿t your teÅ¿timony, out of that alley of errours, where MaÅ¿ter Goodwin lodgeth, (whoÅ¿e compoÅ¿ition is mud and blood) are a Å¿uperÅ¿ufficient teÅ¿timony of the contrary. In his other impure pamphlets he outgoeth all his complices in wickedneÅ¿Å¿e. But in his two laÅ¿t, wherein God did leave him to oppoÅ¿e ChriÅ¿t in your teÅ¿timony, he hath even outgone himÅ¿elfe. I know not one in the world left him to contend with for maÅ¿tery in the black arts of lying and reviling, unleÅ¿Å¿e it be his Å¿tygian teather. In which reÅ¿pect as his tearmes of youngling and novice are notes of no diÅ¿grace to me, Å¿o neither is his hoary and hereticall head found in thoÅ¿e wayes of unrighteouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e an enÅ¿igne of over-abundant honour to him. 'Tis true, his expertneÅ¿Å¿e in lying Å¿peakes him Captain of the Cretian Band, and his skilfulneÅ¿Å¿e in reviling a Doctor fit for the ducking-Å¿toole, though not for the chaire, hut theÅ¿e preferments rather deÅ¿erve pitty than provoke envy. As ambitious to give the world a view of his maturity in the forecited Å¿ins, he addreÅ¿Å¿eth himÅ¿elf againÅ¿t the reverend Å¿ubÅ¿cribers of the late teÅ¿timony in multitudes of paÅ¿Å¿ages, after Å¿uch an odiouÅ¿ly falÅ¿e and reproachfull manner, as thouÅ¿ands of moralliz'd heathens in the world would bluÅ¿h if but deÅ¿ired to do the like. A handfull, in Å¿tead of a vaÅ¿t heap which might be given, are theÅ¿e which follow. To this effect he breathes out reproaches.

MaÅ¿ter Jenkin his reverend and beloved brethren, EpiÅ¿tle to the Reader, p. 4, 5. are theÅ¿e falÅ¿-fingered men, theÅ¿e opprobria & propudia generis humani, The Å¿hames and blots of man-kinde, the vileÅ¿t of men: Their cage is defiled, cleane birds forÅ¿ake them, and it Å¿tands all of this nation in hand whom either the intereÅ¿t of honour or conÅ¿cience toucheth, Å¿peedily to quit communion with them.

In his former pamphlet Syon Colledge was viÅ¿ited, in this latter, 'tis excommunicated, in neither 'tis prejudiced. In caÅ¿ting upon you the names of blots and Å¿pots of mankinde, he is but your Å¿cullion to make your integrity Å¿hine the brighter by all theÅ¿e reproachfull Å¿mutchings; and as he willingly detracts from your reputation, Å¿o he unwillingly adds to your reward. What he relates of the foule and forÅ¿aken cage, clearely Å¿hewes that he accounts meetings for prayer, preaching, purity of reformation, alms to the poore, reliefe to the aged, and for increaÅ¿e of brotherly love, to
be the foule defilements of a place, of which the MiniÅ¿ters having been guilty in their meetings at Sion Colledge, he knoweth that in Å¿tead of Å¿hunning communion with you, the faithfull with a holy Å¿corn neglect his excommunioating of you. The truth is, moÅ¿t of thoÅ¿e whom he accounts to be of his own party, forÅ¿ake and abhominate him if they have any thing of God in them; onely they being (I fear) under the tentation of carnall policy, have not (as yet) fully declared againÅ¿t him, for which the Lord pardon them. MaÅ¿ter Bridg, lately of Holland, whoÅ¿e judgement in this particular I Å¿hall not mention without reÅ¿pect, Å¿aid but a little while Å¿ince among Å¿undry MiniÅ¿ters of my intimate acquaintance, That Å¿ome brethren of them were reÅ¿olved to repaire to MaÅ¿ter Goodwin by way of adviÅ¿ing him to deÅ¿iÅ¿t from maintaining his erroneous opinions touching the Scriptures; and if he refuÅ¿ed Å¿o to do, they reÅ¿olved (he Å¿aid) to quit communion with him; with theÅ¿e or with words to this very purpoÅ¿e did he expreÅ¿Å¿e himÅ¿elf. And I have heard Å¿undry of the Independent judgement Å¿peake of this and his other opinions, propagated in the alley againÅ¿t grace, with the height of abhorrence, and with much profeÅ¿Å¿ed deteÅ¿tation And the truth is, MaÅ¿ter Goodwin in his pretended joyning with the conÅ¿cientious Independent, is lookt upon by the piouÅ¿ly prudent but as a Å¿cabthat cleaveth to the body. He Å¿peakes of clean birds that forÅ¿ake you. A double miÅ¿take; I know but of one that hath forÅ¿aken you, and I wiÅ¿h he were not, MaÅ¿ter Goodwin, in Å¿tead of a cleane bird an unclean heaÅ¿t.

He thus goeth on raving,pag. 5.
There's an old Å¿aw which cuts well:

q.l: Non audet Å¿tygius Pluto tentare quod audet
Effranis flamen â€”

div.p: Which he thus engliÅ¿heth:

q.l: The Prince himÅ¿elf of the black Å¿tygian lake
Dares not attempt what PrieÅ¿ts will undertake.

div.p: In cutting with this Å¿aw he turned the teeth of it the wrong way, I mean from himÅ¿elf toward you, otherwiÅ¿e it wouldhave cut better and quicker thus:

q.l: The Å¿ins which Å¿tygian Pluto dreads
The PrieÅ¿t of Errour-alley Å¿preads.

div.p: But let him turn the teeth of the Å¿aw his owne way, 'tis no diÅ¿grace for you to be taxed with deeds which Satan dares not attempt; and Å¿uch are thoÅ¿e which I mentioned even now to be the deeds of Sion Colledge; nor is it any honour for him to be in harmony with hell, and to conÅ¿pire in the Å¿ame performances with Satan.

He Å¿aith, his Å¿aw cuts well, but whom may he thank? he knowes who it was that did both file the teeth of it, and helpt him to handle it; viz. the prince of Å¿tyx, in Satans Å¿aw pit Å¿chool'd he was.

In another place, drunk with rage, he thus goeth on,Youngl. Elder, pag. 16.
Impiety and oppoÅ¿ition to the truth hang upon Sion Colledge, and if Sion Colledge were removed, impiety and oppoÅ¿ition to the truth would Å¿oone fall to the ground.]

What? Si. Col. a prop of all impieties! could more be Å¿aid for the removall of any Å¿tewes or Å¿tie of fin? 'Tis true, there's much impiety & oppoÅ¿ition to the truth in the Kingdom but, Mr Goodwin, Å¿uppoÅ¿e impiety and oppoÅ¿ition to the truth be Independent, how can they then hang on Sion Colledge? And were that poore Colledge Å¿o loaded with impiety, &c. a removall of it might be Å¿pared, for it would of it Å¿elf certainly and Å¿uddenly fall to the ground. For his intimation of a removall of Sion Colledge, 'tis but a caÅ¿t of his EpiÅ¿copall office. Not long Å¿ince he viÅ¿i â€¢ ed Sion Colledge, even now he excommunicated it, and now he Å¿ues out his Writ de excommunicato capiendo, abÅ¿olving thoÅ¿e from finne that Å¿hall remove it; nay he makes it a moÅ¿t meritorious employment, even the taking away of all impiety and oppoÅ¿ition to the truth. Mean while let him take heed leÅ¿t he be tranÅ¿lated from his BiÅ¿hoprick, and removed to his own place,
Ar. 1.25. before Sion Colledge be removed out of its place: And truly could all his impious errours that Å¿o much oppoÅ¿e the truth be removed with him, his miÅ¿erably miÅ¿-led flock wouldhave a happy change, if his endeavours that they may have his Å¿pirit among them when he is gone have not been too effectuall, and his head be not their directory then, as it is their rubrick now.

He now foams for madneÅ¿Å¿e. For all the Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿e, Youngl. Elder, pag. 25.
either in converting of Å¿oules, unleÅ¿Å¿e it be from God unto Satan; and Å¿o for building up of Å¿oules, unleÅ¿Å¿e it hath been in wrath againÅ¿t the Parliament,
Army, and faithfull Å¿ervants of God, which the MiniÅ¿ters have had for theÅ¿e three or foure yeeres laÅ¿t paÅ¿t, I am full of rationall confidence, that it may be caÅ¿t up with a cypher, and meaÅ¿ured with a reed that never grew.

In one thing you may obÅ¿erve MaÅ¿ter Goodwins modeÅ¿ty, he only Å¿aith, That for theÅ¿e three or foure yeeres you have converted none; but I have Å¿poken with Å¿ome very gracious ChriÅ¿tians, who have been exact obÅ¿ervers of MaÅ¿ter Goodwins MiniÅ¿try, and they told me, That they never heard or perceived that ever God bleÅ¿Å¿ed it with the turning of any one Å¿inner toward God. How many he hath turn'd from God, its not Å¿o eaÅ¿ie to determine as 'tis to Å¿ear.

But the totall inÅ¿ucceÅ¿Å¿efulneÅ¿Å¿e of your MiniÅ¿try in the converÅ¿ion of none, is Å¿uch a putid calumny, that even the Å¿ectaries read it with bluÅ¿hing, and when they are told of it, they turne their heads another way, and pretend 'tis for conveniency of Å¿pitting; It may be your grief you are Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿efull in converting no more; your comfort you are Å¿ucceÅ¿Å¿efull in converting Å¿ome; your confidence that he is a Å¿oul perverter, or at leaÅ¿t that the way to convert men, is not to teach that men can convert themÅ¿elves. His trouble it is, that any are converted by you from his errours. But if he thinkes that there is no converÅ¿ion of Å¿oules in our Churches, what will he and his Collegues do for new recruits? their trade of Sheep-Å¿tealing will quite decay, for I have heard that Å¿undry of themÅ¿elves do not Å¿o much as pretend to preach for converÅ¿ion of Å¿oules.

As for my Å¿elfe, I Å¿ee no other import or tendency (as he cants it) in this his fooliÅ¿h pamphlet, but onely by reviling to vilifie me (though I can, bleÅ¿Å¿ed be God, Å¿ay with JoÅ¿eph, God hath meant it unto good for me, yea, unto a good contrary to the evill of reproaching,) and therefore more than one hundred times doth he in this his rayling paÅ¿quill expreÅ¿Å¿e himÅ¿elfe againÅ¿t me in Å¿uch termes as theÅ¿e: Youngling, novice, boy, childe, youth, young Å¿pringlius, young glorioÅ¿o, young ignaro, young Phaeton, vaine young man, unworthy young man, young Jenkins, young Å¿implicius, childling, young Pragmatico, Å¿hameleÅ¿Å¿e young man, young Dictator, young Metropolitan, young ThraÅ¿o, green-head, young peece of preÅ¿umption, Prelaticall peece of Presbytery, unhallowed peece of Presbytery, Å¿welling
peece of vanity, Å¿an of Å¿hame and folly, illiterate Å¿oule, poore man, Å¿illy brain, mancipium of illiterateneÅ¿Å¿e, friend William, Batte mi fili, (as if with his religion and reaÅ¿on, he had alÅ¿o abjured good manners.) And he plainly tels his Reader, that his aime in writing his booke was thus: To make me know my Å¿elfe; though a gracious heart would have put him upon writing to have made the people know the truth.

Touching his reproaches for my want of yeers, I could Å¿ay: That I was ordained Presbyter about ten yeares before Mr. Goodwin commenced Independent; That I learned thoÅ¿e rudiments of Logick above 20. yeares ago in the UniverÅ¿ity of Cambridge, which MaÅ¿ter Goodwin is now defective in, either by never learning them, or forgetting them, as is cleere by Å¿undry paÅ¿Å¿ages in his Booke which I have mentioned in this. That if I be Å¿o young, I am in part excuÅ¿ed for my illiterateneÅ¿Å¿e, my times (it Å¿eems) having been Å¿hort as well as my attainments. That I grant, Mr. Goodwins book Å¿peaks him old, particularly, that paÅ¿Å¿age of his, p. 2. To. Eld. where he Å¿peaks his owne Å¿eniority thus: The worÅ¿e Å¿pirits of malignity, hypocriÅ¿ie, Å¿earedneÅ¿Å¿e of conÅ¿cience, diÅ¿Å¿imulation of the truth. &c. do not often finde men out till they be Å¿tricken in yeeres. As for the reÅ¿idue of his Pamphlet it Å¿peaks him old even to dotage, which is to be a childe twice and alwayes. That were I Å¿o young as he pretends, yet he cannot prove the falÅ¿eneÅ¿Å¿e of my aÅ¿Å¿ertions by the fewneÅ¿Å¿e of my yeeres, though this be the Å¿trongeÅ¿t argument in all his booke againÅ¿t what I write, his only indeavour being to make my booke a Å¿ufferer by my yeeres, becauÅ¿e he cannot make my yeeres to Å¿uffer by my booke. That were there Å¿o great a diÅ¿parity of yeeres between us, yet truth is Å¿enior to us both, and he and his errours are more younglings to truth than I am to him, though I grant his Errours to â€¢â€¢ ing grace, as old as Pelagius.

Touching that other imputation of illiterateneÅ¿Å¿e; I Å¿ay I am Å¿o far from diÅ¿liking this his charge, that I Å¿hould have bin very well Å¿atisfied if Å¿undry who exceed MaÅ¿ter Goodwin in Å¿tanding, and very much in underÅ¿tanding, had paÅ¿Å¿ed the Å¿ame cenÅ¿ure upon me that he hath done, and never another. That as he hath not Å¿o much learning as to allow him to boaÅ¿t, Å¿o I have not Å¿o little as to Å¿uffer me to be unthankfull. That he hath diÅ¿honoured
himÅ¿elf in the undertaking, nay in the overcomming (were he victor) much more inbeing overcome by one Å¿o illiterate; having muÅ¿tered Å¿uch a vaÅ¿t body, Å¿uch a huge book to purÅ¿ue a flea, wherein every line is at leaÅ¿t either a pike or a musket; Å¿hould he vanquiÅ¿h it would be no honour to him, Å¿hould he be vanquiÅ¿ht the diÅ¿grace would be indelible. That Å¿undry, not contemptible, have had but low eÅ¿timations of Mr. Goodwins literature. Famous Doctor Stoughton obÅ¿erving how MaÅ¿ter Goodwin was wont to torture Scripture for the defending of his errors which in thoÅ¿e dayes he vented in his Sermons, uÅ¿ed this compariÅ¿on in the hearing of an eminent MiniÅ¿ter now in London, As an hungry dog that teareth and gnaweth upon a dry bone, and can Å¿uck nothing out of it for the relief of his appetite, by long gnawing upon it, wets it all over with the unclean moyÅ¿ture of his own mouth, and at length for hunger Å¿ucks in that moyÅ¿ture againe as if he had been beholding to the bone for it; Å¿o, Å¿aid he, did Mr. Goodwin teare the holy Scriptures to draw out a Å¿enÅ¿e that might countenance his unlearned and corrupt opinions, which he not able to obtaine, (the Scriptures being dry to Å¿uch intents) the Å¿purious expoÅ¿itions that flowed out of his owne month upon the Scriptures in his tedious tozing of them, he confidently Å¿ucks in againe, as if they had been the contributions of the Scriptures themÅ¿elves. Mr. C. a MiniÅ¿ter of good worth, now in London, and MiniÅ¿ter of Ma. neare the be. whether upon obÅ¿erving the darkneÅ¿Å¿e of Mr. Goodwins way in expounding, or rather his darkning in Å¿tead of expounding Scripture, or otherwiÅ¿e, Å¿ometimes Å¿aid, Mr. Goodwin was like a horÅ¿e that went into a very clear Å¿treame, but coming forth againe, he left it by pawing with his feet, very thick and muddy. And indeed he is no better at the pen than in the pulpit; for in making all his pamphlets, he Å¿eems to dip his pe â€¢ , or rather his pia mater, in puddle-dock. A reverend CommiÅ¿Å¿ioner, and a learned MiniÅ¿ter of the Church of Scotland, having one of thoÅ¿e wretched pamphlets called Sion Colledge viÅ¿ited Å¿ent him, in his letter Å¿hortly after returned, he uÅ¿ed only this Å¿hort but Å¿harp expreÅ¿Å¿ion concerning it, Goodwin is a beaÅ¿t, The paÅ¿Å¿age I reade.

Touching that imputation of Prelaticall peece of Presbytery, I Å¿ay, my principles, preaching, and other practiÅ¿es, are and
ever Å¿hall be, by Gods grace, oppoÅ¿ite to Prelacy, becauÅ¿e my conÅ¿cience tels me that Prelacy Å¿o much oppoÅ¿eth the Word; under Prelacy I was an early Å¿ufferer. At Cambr. long Å¿ince I was forced to forÅ¿ake my otherwiÅ¿e dear Colledge, becauÅ¿e I durÅ¿t not ful mit to popiÅ¿h and prelaticall innovations, and to betake my Å¿elf to another Colledge in the Å¿ame UniverÅ¿ity, where I enjoyed liberty for Å¿tudy Å¿undry yeares with out thoÅ¿e Prelaticall impoÅ¿itions; and Å¿undry are able to teÅ¿tifie how fierce the rage of the Prelaticall faction was againÅ¿t me a long time in the univerÅ¿ity, and afterwards; though I Å¿ay not that MaÅ¿ter Goodwin was connived at, and Å¿ecretly encouraged to vent his opinions in ColemanÅ¿treet, when the faithfull Min â€¢ Å¿ters of the City were Å¿ilenced and perÅ¿ecuted.

You have had a taÅ¿te of his reproaches; behold him now making lyes his refuge. He relates two Å¿tories concerning you, which together with his deÅ¿cants upon them, are the Å¿ubject matter of moÅ¿t part of his EpiÅ¿tle; but there is Å¿carce a word in either of them, in the writing whereof, his fingers were not wofully troubled with the Cretian cramp.

In his firÅ¿t Å¿tory he tels the Reader, Pag. 2, 3. of his EpiÅ¿t. That although n a Provinciall meeting, it was reÅ¿olved upon the queÅ¿tion, That no anÅ¿wer Å¿hould be given to his booke called Sion Colledge viÅ¿ited, and (he hopeth out of Å¿enÅ¿e of his innocency) that the graver judicatory had determined his immunity as Pilate did ChriÅ¿ts, yet MaÅ¿ter Jenkins like the Jewes, who would needs have ChriÅ¿t crucified, hath made log furrowes upon his back, &c.

A Å¿tory that hath not fewer than fore of five of the foreÅ¿aid Cretian commodities in it. For firÅ¿t, The Provinciall meeting never propounded, much leÅ¿e made any reÅ¿olution upon, any queÅ¿tion concerning the anÅ¿wering or not anÅ¿wering his book. 2. Never was it reÅ¿olved in any of your meetings, that his book Å¿hould not be anÅ¿wered; indeed it was generally conceived that Å¿o empty a pamphlet deÅ¿erved not to be anÅ¿wered by any. So that 3. the forbearance to put any upon the imployment of anÅ¿wering his book, was not out of Å¿enÅ¿e of his innocency, but out of apprehenÅ¿ion of his impotenoy; you looking upon him as Å¿even fold more the Å¿on of Å¿hame ant folly after the publiÅ¿hing of his Sion Colledge viÅ¿ited than he Å¿hewed himÅ¿elf before. 4. Never
did Mr. Jenkin make furrowes upon his back, he onely Å¿hew'd the deep furrowes that Mr. Goodwin had made upon the back of truth with the plow of his pen, Satan guiding and driving it moÅ¿t commonly for him. And I know nothing that was laid upon his back but a rod, (according to Salomons advice) and that too of his own making. Sorry I am, that inÅ¿tead of making him to mend, it hath occaÅ¿ioned him to be mad.

In his Å¿econd Å¿tory he tels his Reader, that the Archytects of the deÅ¿igne (he meanes of teÅ¿ti â€¢ ying againÅ¿t his errors) obtained the Å¿ubÅ¿criptions of MaÅ¿ter John Downame to a paper, wherein was not the leaÅ¿t mention of any of his Errors, and after, Mr. Downames band was obtained, they foyÅ¿ted into the Catalogue of Errours what Å¿ayings they pleaÅ¿ed.
Captain CretenÅ¿is is upon his march, but I Å¿hall Å¿top him. The relation conÅ¿iÅ¿teth of two as odious untruths as ever dropt from a Cretians quill. For.

FirÅ¿t, I affirm, that the Errours of MaÅ¿ter Goodwin were mentioned and Å¿et downe in the Catalogue in that fulneÅ¿Å¿e and order wherein they are now expreÅ¿Å¿ed, nay diÅ¿tinctly read in the bearing of MaÅ¿ter John Downame, before be Å¿ubÅ¿cribed his band to the paper for the witneÅ¿Å¿ing againÅ¿t them.
2. No Å¿ayings of Mr. Goodwin, or of any other of the Sectaries mentioned in the Catalogue, were put into the Catalogue of Errours after MaÅ¿ter Downames hand was obtained.

The former MaÅ¿ter Downame hath acknowledged to two or three Reverend MiniÅ¿ters that went to him on purpoÅ¿e for enquiry, at the Å¿ame time expreÅ¿Å¿ing to them his abhorring of Mr. Goodwins opinions mentioned in the Catalogue; which I rather relate, becauÅ¿e he termes Mr. Downame learned, and one of the beÅ¿t Å¿pirited men. I like the expreÅ¿Å¿ions, with this note, that Å¿uch men moÅ¿t deteÅ¿t Mr Goodwins Errours.

Two deteÅ¿table lied are contained in that relation of his, pag. 78. To. Eld. where he Å¿aith, That not long Å¿ince Å¿ome of his followers came to me to propound their Å¿crup â€¢ es about the Dectrine that I had taught, concerning the nature of a true Church, and that contrary to my ã€ˆâ€¦ã€‰ promiÅ¿e, I denyed conference with them, and that I refuÅ¿ed to diÅ¿pute with them unleÅ¿Å¿e by writing. The truth is this, many Sectaries (obÅ¿erving how Å¿undry ChriÅ¿tians (I deÅ¿ire to
mention it with humble thankfulnes) were Å¿trengthened againÅ¿t the SchiÅ¿me of Independency, by the Sermons which I preached neer three yeeres Å¿ince, concerning a true viÅ¿ible Church) were filled and cut to the heart with madneÅ¿Å¿e. At which time Å¿ome of Mr. Goodwins followers, upon a Lords day toward evening came to my houÅ¿e, Å¿undry of my ChriÅ¿tian friends in my owne pariÅ¿h coming with them, to obÅ¿erve (as I conceive) their deportment. Where one or two of Mr. Goodwins followers that had a minde to Å¿peak more than the reÅ¿t, diÅ¿covered that Å¿hamefull ignorance in cavelling, that divers of thoÅ¿e that flood by, and Å¿ome of their owne party, as afterward they confeÅ¿Å¿ed, bluÅ¿h â€¢ d to hear them; my Å¿elf alÅ¿o wondring at their empty impudence; they being Å¿o farre from bringing any objection againÅ¿t what I had delivered, that they were not able without my prompting them to tell me what particular paÅ¿Å¿age in my Sermon it was againÅ¿t which they took exception. Only they knew, that what I had delivered made againÅ¿t them, and they were reÅ¿olved that they would not like it. But Å¿o far was I from refuÅ¿ing conference with them, that I entertained neare two houres diÅ¿courÅ¿e with them at that time, though I had preached twice that Sabboth, my body being thereby very faint and weary; expreÅ¿Å¿ing alÅ¿o the greateÅ¿t forwardneÅ¿Å¿e and willingneÅ¿Å¿e to informe and Å¿atisfie them whenÅ¿oever they pleaÅ¿ed, and deÅ¿iring them to that end to come to my houÅ¿e, for indeed I much pittied them. To be Å¿hort, it wat at length propounded by one of my friends, that my Å¿elf and two MiniÅ¿ters might diÅ¿pute with three of theirs who were of a contrary judgement concerning the points in controverÅ¿ie, for the Å¿atisfaction of the unÅ¿etled Gentlemen. This motion I embraced moÅ¿t willingly, and deÅ¿ired them to certifie Å¿o much to their MiniÅ¿ters, which they promiÅ¿ed to do; and upon advice taken with Å¿ome reverend brethren concerning the fitteÅ¿t and profitableÅ¿t manner of managing the Å¿aid diÅ¿putation, I made this offer under my hand in writing, and Å¿ent it by Å¿ome of the unÅ¿etled Gentlemen, viz. That I would Å¿end their MiniÅ¿ters the heads of all my Sermons, with all thoÅ¿e poÅ¿itions contained in them, that oppoÅ¿ed the way of Å¿eparation; and if they would ingage to anÅ¿wer them in print, I promiÅ¿ed alÅ¿o to publiÅ¿h a reply in print
to that their anÅ¿wer, that Å¿o all the world might Å¿ee on which fide the truth lay. But this offer, Å¿avouring too much of plaine dealing, and love of the light, their Minihers accepted not, pretending their mighty imployments. The MiniÅ¿ters refuÅ¿ing the diÅ¿cuÅ¿Å¿ion of the controverÅ¿ie by way of writing, though Å¿olicited thereto by my Letter, what followed: why now my Gentlemen (to make up in Å¿obriety what they wanted in Å¿etledneÅ¿Å¿e) having it Å¿eems leiÅ¿ure enough, earneÅ¿tly deÅ¿ire that I would engage with them in writing. This I refuÅ¿ed, holding my Å¿elf cloÅ¿e to my former offers, that if any of them were unÅ¿atisfied, I would endeavour moÅ¿t willingly in a private way of conference to inform them, conceiving that this might content them who aimed at information and not at oÅ¿tentation. In this relation therefore of Mr. Goodwins, I charge him with theÅ¿e two broad faced falÅ¿ities: 1. His Å¿aying, That I refuÅ¿ed conference with his followers, whereas I earneÅ¿tly invited them to come to me for that end. 2. His Å¿aying, That I was adviÅ¿ed by my brethren to diÅ¿pute with his followers only by writing, whereas I never was adviÅ¿ed or offered at all to diÅ¿pute with them by writing; my offer to diÅ¿pute by writing or printing, being onely made to their MiniÅ¿ters, or thoÅ¿e Å¿o called.

In a coole requitall for theÅ¿e three rotten and falÅ¿e Å¿tories, in two of which he baÅ¿ely Å¿landers Å¿o many of his betters, I Å¿hall onely Å¿uccinctly Å¿hew how much more he hath abuÅ¿ed himÅ¿elfe in his Youngl. Elder, than he hath all or any of you, by his foule and falÅ¿e repreÅ¿entations.

For the wronging of his owne reputation, (if at leaÅ¿t it could be made worÅ¿e than it was before) by his late pamphlet called, The Youngling Elder, to Å¿ay nothing here, how cheap and worthles he hath made his Å¿criblings by the Å¿cores of pages Å¿pent in Å¿uch raylings, as the common obÅ¿ervations and light of every reader doth confute (Å¿cum and Å¿currility making up his whole book.) I Å¿hall onely obÅ¿erve how Å¿hameleÅ¿Å¿e and ridiculous he is in magnifying and extolling himÅ¿elf, pretending himÅ¿elf to be the moÅ¿t dreadfull adverÅ¿ary that ever put on gowne or â€¢ antlet, bragging, and Å¿waggering, and boaÅ¿ting, and ranting, and rufling, in the beginning of his book, as if he
would bury ten Å¿uch younglings as my Å¿elf in one furrow of his brow; and as if he would affright the whole world into a forbearance of quetching againÅ¿t him, by the terror of my example; when as, alas, in the Å¿equell of his booke he is Å¿o wretchedly weake, and ridiculouÅ¿ly empty, that inÅ¿tead of making me to bleed with his force, he onely makes me to bluÅ¿h at his folly.

Speaking concerning my hazardous adventures in dealing with him,pag. 3. he thus inÅ¿ults: Little doth this poore man know what be hath done. Presbytery lies bleeding at the Å¿oot of my writings, and is as good as broken in peeces by them; it is Å¿haken, Å¿hattered, and diÅ¿mantled by them. When I write I feele the Å¿trength of God neare me. pag. 17.
I have had to do with the keeneÅ¿t Å¿ons of high Presbytery, pag. 5, Ep. whoÅ¿e little finger had more weight than MaÅ¿ter Jenkins loyns, and yet I have laid all their attempts and writing in the duÅ¿t, as well they did deÅ¿erve, and therefore this young man was of no deep reach, becauÅ¿e he feared not the Å¿ame iÅ¿Å¿ue. Exempla gratia, p. 26. Y. El. You laid MaÅ¿ter Walker and MaÅ¿ter Robroughs writings in the duÅ¿t; with the former of which you encountred as an aÅ¿Å¿e with a lyon; and with the latter of which you never durÅ¿t enter the LiÅ¿ts, though provoked by an elaborate TreatiÅ¿e in confutation of your errors about juÅ¿tification. So you laid MaÅ¿ter Edwards his Antapologia in the duÅ¿t; a booke that Å¿o fully and clearly detected your frauds, that inÅ¿tead of anÅ¿wering the matter of it by Scripture or reaÅ¿on, you were faine to betake your Å¿elf to your Grammer, and only here and there Å¿narle at the Å¿eeming improperneÅ¿Å¿e of a word. He threatens, That before he and his friend William part, he will make him as hereticall as himÅ¿elfe, &c. And rather than he will not prove himÅ¿elf a boaÅ¿ter, he makes himÅ¿elf a ballad-maker; he Å¿aith. or rather Å¿aweth thus, in the height of menacing:

q.l: The time will come that youthfull Turnus Å¿hall
WiÅ¿h dearly Pallas ne â€¢ 'r had been encountred.

div.p: But why rather makes he not uÅ¿e of the skill of a far better Poet, who brings in MaÅ¿ter Goodwins younger brother, expreÅ¿Å¿ing himÅ¿elf thus to David:

q.l: â€” Art thou weary of thy life Å¿o Å¿ â€¢ one,
O fooliÅ¿h bay, phantaÅ¿ticall baboon.
â€” I will not file
My feared hands with blood Å¿o faintly vile,
Go Å¿eeke thy match, thou Å¿hale not dye by me,
Thine honour Å¿hall not my diÅ¿honour be,
No (Å¿illy lad) no, wert thou of the Gods,
I would not fight at Å¿o unknightly odds.

div.p:
This, among the reÅ¿t of the characters of thoÅ¿e ungodly men, Å¿poken of by Paul and Peter, 2 Tim. 2.3, 4. 2 Pet. 2.18. ã€ˆ in non-Latin alphabet ã€‰ . agrees with him, to be fierce and high minded, to Å¿peak great Å¿welling words of vanity. He expreÅ¿Å¿ing himÅ¿elf more like a RuÅ¿Å¿ian than a MiniÅ¿ter; he Å¿hining not like a Å¿weetly influentiall Å¿tar, but flaÅ¿hing like an angry bloody Comet, he Å¿peaking after the rate of the eldeÅ¿t Å¿onne of Godmagog; more like a Polyphemus than like a Paul; more like a Å¿waÅ¿h-buckler than a BiÅ¿hop; a Lamech than a MoÅ¿es; and expreÅ¿Å¿ing more the preÅ¿umption of Behemoth,
Job 40.23. who truÅ¿teth that be can draw up Jordan into his mouth, than the lamb-like Å¿pirit of a Saint. In a word, he hath Å¿o much of the Goodwin, that be hath nothing at all of the John in him, for

q.l: â€” From his eyes
All drunke with rage and blood, the lightning flyes
Out of his beaver like a boar be foams,
A belliÅ¿h fury in his boÅ¿ome roams.

div.p: But alas this Ivye-buÅ¿h of boaÅ¿ting doth but Å¿hew the badneÅ¿Å¿e of his wine to all prudent paÅ¿Å¿engers; his booke is a meer thundring trifle, a mountaine of chaffe, a terriculament, onely for the ignorant of the alley; like the logg in the fable, it makes a great noiÅ¿e in its falling, but then it lies Å¿till for every frog to skip upon it.

The truth is, he might well have Å¿pared the paines of Å¿etting his name unto it, for Å¿o poor a weakling, and Å¿o miÅ¿hapen a monÅ¿ter it is, that as none will challenge it for theirs, Å¿o none will doubt it for his; although in two regards it be very unlike the father, it having a rich and a full bead, (a Å¿tuffed title) and a thin empty body; the reÅ¿idue of the book.

He doth not Å¿o much as pretend to anÅ¿wer the greateÅ¿t part by far of what I bring in oppoÅ¿ition to his errours. There's not Å¿o much as any mention in his Youngling Elder of the moÅ¿t materiall paÅ¿Å¿ages contained in mine; but he prudently paÅ¿Å¿eth
them by in learned Å¿ilence, and onely here and there toucheth Å¿uperficially upon a few by-paÅ¿Å¿ages, (not but that he was able I trow, with the leaÅ¿t puffe to Å¿end them all on an errand to the wormes, had not his owne goodneÅ¿Å¿e and noble nature more prevailed with him than any merit in Å¿uch a naughty youth as I) Å¿o that as to the buÅ¿ineÅ¿Å¿e of anÅ¿wering me, his booke is a meer by-work, and indeed among all judicious men a meer byword; which he prudently foreÅ¿eeing, confeÅ¿Å¿eth by way of anticipation, that his booke is not a formall confutation of mine, but that his end in fetting of it forth,EpiÅ¿tle to the Reader, was to make me know my Å¿elfe; but of his childiÅ¿h and impotent omiÅ¿Å¿ions I Å¿hall (God willing) give a more particular account in the following Chapter. But if at any time he doth vonchÅ¿afe a mentioning of any of my paÅ¿Å¿ages againÅ¿t him; inÅ¿tead of an anÅ¿wer he either brings Å¿coffs and reproaches, or elÅ¿e he labours to do the work of an opponent, bringing in Å¿tead of a Å¿olution of my arguments, a bumble of muÅ¿ty reaÅ¿ons, taken out of his other books to fill up paper in this; or elÅ¿e his poore Å¿ew anÅ¿wers are Å¿o miÅ¿erably unÅ¿atisfactory, impertinent, and hereticall, that this his laÅ¿t worke appeares plainely to be the iÅ¿Å¿ue of his very dotage to all impartiall obÅ¿ervers.

I Å¿hall onely in this fi â€¢ Å¿t Chapter barely recite Å¿ome of his anÅ¿wers to Å¿ome places of Scripture and paÅ¿Å¿ages contained in my booke; reÅ¿erving the refutation of them to the third and fourth Chapters, though indeed the recitation of Å¿uch cheape and poore Å¿tuffe, be a Å¿ufficient refutation of them among intelligent Readers.

The places of Scripture which I bring againÅ¿t his Errours, he either wholly paÅ¿Å¿eth by, as if they had never been alledged by me, (and thus he dealeth with all thoÅ¿e many places which I alledge againÅ¿t his Errours about the Scripture) or elÅ¿e if he pretends to anÅ¿wer them, he puts Å¿uch falÅ¿e and unÅ¿ound gloÅ¿Å¿es upon them, that he Å¿peakes himÅ¿elf moÅ¿t erroneous, even when he goeth about to cleere himÅ¿elfe from errour; like the Å¿wearer, that being reproved for his oathes, Å¿ware with a greater oath that he did not Å¿wear.

To that place Acts 26.18. where Paul declares, That he was Å¿ent to the Gentiles to open their eyes, &c. I having Å¿aid, That converÅ¿ion
is the reÅ¿toring of Å¿ight, not of light onely, T. El. p. 54. he aÅ¿Å¿erts moÅ¿t prophanely and erronouÅ¿ly, that mens eyes are onely opened in converÅ¿ion as the light of the morning or the Å¿un may be Å¿aid to open a mans eyes which were Å¿hut by the darkneÅ¿Å¿e of the night; Å¿o that naturall men have good eyes, onely they are in the darke, there's nothing periÅ¿ht in the faculty of Å¿eeing.

To that place,Yo. Eld. p 55. EpiÅ¿t. 2. dead in treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿es and Å¿ins. he anÅ¿wers, by Å¿aying the meaning onely is, That they of whom the ApoÅ¿tle Å¿peaks, were guilty of death, and liable to condemnation.

The meaning of that place,Yo. Eld. p. 87. 1 Cor. 2.14. The naturall man receiveth not the things of the Å¿pirit of God, neither can be know them, &c. he gives us thus, by the naturall man, he Å¿aith, is not meant the man that is Å¿imply or meerly naturall or unregener are, but Å¿uch a kinde of men as are babes in ChriÅ¿t; and whereas its Å¿aid, be cannot know the things of the Å¿pirit of God; Yo. Eld. p. 89. this profound expoÅ¿iter of Scripture gives us this to be the meaning: The naturall man whileÅ¿t he continues thus, bath not a power actually and for the preÅ¿ent, to know Å¿imply the things of the Å¿pirit, but he hath Å¿uch principles which by a due and regular improvement may advance and riÅ¿e into Å¿uch a capacity or power as is contended for.

That place of 1 Cor. 4.7.Yo. Eld. p. 59.
Who maketh thee to differ; he tels us, is not to be underÅ¿tood of any difference betweene man and man which is made by any Å¿aving worke, but of Å¿uch a difference onely which Å¿tands in more or fewer, or in greater or leÅ¿Å¿er gifts; which difference in the primitive times was frequent.

He having Å¿aid, That no writings, originals, or tranÅ¿lations, are the Word of God, the matter and Å¿ubÅ¿tance of things (as that ChriÅ¿t is God, is Man; that be dyed, that be roÅ¿e from the dead, &c.) conteyned in the books of the Old and New TeÅ¿tament, being by him acknowledged only for the word of God. I demand of him thus. Bu. p. 22. how can any beleeve that the matter and Å¿ubÅ¿tance of the Scripture, as that ChriÅ¿t is God and Man, &c is the Word of God, when as be muÅ¿t be uncertaine whether the written word wherein that matter is conteyned is the Word of God or no; This hereticall and rediculous Å¿oul fetcheth off himÅ¿elf thus, by asking me againe, Cannot a man beleeve theÅ¿e matters conteyned in the Scripture, The Sun is the greater light, and the Moon the leÅ¿Å¿er light, unleÅ¿Å¿e he be certaine that the written word is the Word of God?

To my charge, of his joyning hands with the Arminians in heir errours, concerning power to good Å¿upernaturall, he anÅ¿wers â€¢ ot a Å¿illable by way of denying the charge, but tels me, That in holding JeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t to be they holy one of God, Yo. Eld. p. 43. Y. El. p. 44. I joyn hands with the Devill. Yea, he Å¿aith the Arminians attribute all the praiÅ¿e of converÅ¿ion to God.

Nay, he Å¿lights and neglects as much the accuÅ¿ation of agreement with Pelagius in his Errours, impudently affirming,Youngl. Elder, pag. 52. that between AuguÅ¿tine and Pelagius there was little or no difference.

To my allegations out of the Fathers and Bucer, for vindicating either of the Scriptures or the grace of God, he anÅ¿wereth not a word. And inÅ¿tead of doing Å¿o, when I bring multitudes of evident places out of them, to Å¿hew how thoÅ¿e places which he wreÅ¿teth ought to be underÅ¿tood, he very modeÅ¿tly rather than they Å¿hall not be though to Å¿peak for him in Å¿ome few places, tels us that they contradict themÅ¿elves in all the reÅ¿t.

To cite (Å¿aith he) other words of a contrary import to thoÅ¿e qu â€¢ ted by me out of the Å¿ame Author, is no manifeÅ¿tation of the impertinency of my quotations; Yo. Eld. p. 5.
but it is indeed a diÅ¿covering of the nakedneÅ¿Å¿e of an Auth â€¢ r, to preÅ¿ent him contradictious to himÅ¿elfe, and to expoÅ¿e the unÅ¿tableneÅ¿Å¿e of his judgement to the eyes of men; So that
â€¢ ucer, Ball, AuguÅ¿tine, Hierome, are Å¿elf-contradictors, unÅ¿table, naked, unable, rather than this petty-toes of a Pope can erre an haires breadth.

He Å¿coffs at the abÅ¿olute decree, and Å¿aith,Yo. Eld. p 10. That I and my mates tremble not to inform the creature againÅ¿t the Creator, as if from eternity be had Å¿hut up his grace, &c. with the iron barres of an irreverÅ¿ible indiÅ¿penÅ¿able decree.

He tels us pag. 62. that ther's nothin but morall perÅ¿waÅ¿ion to act the will into a Å¿aving conÅ¿ent,Yo. Eld. p. 62. pag. 63. for thus he wanders. It paÅ¿Å¿eth my underÅ¿tanding to conceive how the will Å¿hould be wrought or acted into a conÅ¿ent in any kinde otherwiÅ¿e than by argument, motive and perÅ¿waÅ¿ion, unleÅ¿Å¿e it be by force, violence, and compulÅ¿ion. The eÅ¿Å¿entiall conÅ¿titution and fal â€¢ ick of the will exempt it from being drawnely an other meanes.
And page 65. he thus debaÅ¿eth the working of Gods grace, There is no man converted actually, but might poÅ¿Å¿ibly have acted or demeaned himÅ¿elfe Å¿o as never to have been thus converted.
And pag. 52. The adjutory of grace doth not imply a neceÅ¿Å¿ity of effecting that which is effected by it.
But of his omiÅ¿Å¿ions, and Å¿lender and erroneous performances, you may pleaÅ¿e more fully to take this following account in theÅ¿e three following Chapters.

div.head: CHAP. II.

argument.p: Shewing MaÅ¿ter Goodwin his omiÅ¿Å¿ions in his Youngling Elder, and totall paÅ¿Å¿ing by of moÅ¿t of the materiall paÅ¿Å¿ages contained in my booke called, The buÅ¿ie BiÅ¿hop, againÅ¿t his pamphlet called, Sion Coll. viÅ¿ited, by way of parallel.

div.head: AÅ¿Å¿erted in Sion Colledge viÅ¿ited.
div.p:
IT was never well with ChriÅ¿tian Religion, Å¿ince the MiniÅ¿ters of the GoÅ¿pell (Å¿o called by themÅ¿elves, and Å¿o reputed by the generality of men for want of knowing better) cunningly veÅ¿ted that priviledge of theChurch of being the ground and pillar of truth in
themÅ¿elves. There came lately out of the preÅ¿Å¿e a few papers, Å¿tiling themÅ¿elves, A teÅ¿timony to the truth, &c. and pretending to a Å¿ubÅ¿cription by the MiniÅ¿t. of ChriÅ¿t, &c. Sion Coll. viÅ¿ited, pag. 1.

It is a precious truth
of JeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, That no act of man what Å¿oever is any foundation of ChriÅ¿tian Religion, the ApoÅ¿tle affi â€¢ ming that other foundation can no man lay but JeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t, 1 Cor. 3.11. and yet the denyall of the act of man to be a foundation of ChriÅ¿tian Religion(as viz. The beleeving that the Scriptures are the Word of God) is by the Å¿aid Booke called, A TeÅ¿timony to the truth, ranked among infamous and pernicious errours. Sion Colledge â€¢ Å¿ited, pag. 3.

You cite Å¿ome of my words barely, Å¿uppreÅ¿Å¿ing craftily my Å¿enÅ¿e. You cite theÅ¿e words: QueÅ¿tionleÅ¿Å¿e no writing whatÅ¿oever, whether tranÅ¿lations or originals, are the Word â€¢ f
God, Divine Author, pag. 18. without citing thoÅ¿e other words of mine, Divine Author, pag. 13. wherein I aÅ¿Å¿ert them to be of Divine Authority, Si. Coll. viÅ¿ited, p. 11, 12.
Let the thirteenth and fifteenth pages of Divine Author be lookt upon, pag. 12. Sion Coll. viÅ¿ited.

I beÅ¿eech you brethren, where lyes the error of theÅ¿e words? ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰
God Å¿hould not endue men with Å¿uch principles, abilities, &c. by the diligent improvement whereof they might come to be convin â€¢ ed of a readineÅ¿Å¿e, and willingneÅ¿Å¿e in him to receive them into grace and favour upon their repentance, and turning to him(upon which conviction that repentance and turning to God alwaies followes) they which are condemned would have their mouthes opened againÅ¿t God, and Å¿urmÅ¿hed with and excuÅ¿e, &c.

The Å¿um of his paÅ¿Å¿age cited for an error in our teÅ¿timonie is this: If God Å¿hould deprive men of all power to beleeve, & yet perÅ¿wade
to beleeve, &c. God would be like a King that cauÅ¿eth a mans legs to be cut off, and yet urgeth him to run a Race with thoÅ¿e that have limbs. Div. Au. p. 168.
Naturall men may doe Å¿uch things as whereunto God hath by way of promiÅ¿e annexed grace and acceptation.

All the world, even thoÅ¿e that have not the letter of the GoÅ¿pell, have yet Å¿ufficient meanes granted them of beleeving theÅ¿e two, viz. That God is, and that he is a rewarder of them that diligently Å¿eeke him; which is all the faith that the ApoÅ¿tle
makes neceÅ¿Å¿ary to bring a man into grace or favour with god. They who have only the heavens, the Å¿un, m one, and Å¿tarrs to preach the GoÅ¿pell to them, have alÅ¿o reaÅ¿on Å¿ufficient, to judge the Å¿ame judgment with them who have the letter of the GoÅ¿pell, for they have the GoÅ¿pell, the Å¿ubÅ¿tance and effect of it, the willingneÅ¿Å¿e of God to be reconciled to the world, preached unto them by the ApoÅ¿tles aforeÅ¿aid, the Å¿un, moone, and Å¿tars. Div. Auth. p. 183. p. 186

Nor were it a matter of much more difficulty to bring antiquity it Å¿elfe, and particularly thoÅ¿e very Authors who were the greateÅ¿t oppoÅ¿ers of Pelagius, as Hierom, AuguÅ¿t. ProÅ¿per, &c. with mouthes wide open, in approbation of the Å¿ame things for which I am arraigned at the tribunall of Sion Col. Sion Col. ViÅ¿. p. 24.
TheÅ¿e men have exchanged the Fathers adjutorium, into their owne compulÅ¿orium. Sion Col. ViÅ¿. p. 28.

The queÅ¿tion between Pelagius and the Fathers, was not whether man had freedome of will in reÅ¿pect of good or evill, but whether men notwithhÅ¿tanding their freedome of will, did not Å¿till Å¿tand in need of the adjutory of grace, both for the performance of, and perÅ¿everance in what was good.

div.head: AnÅ¿wered in buÅ¿ie BiÅ¿hop.
div.p:
1. TIs you Å¿orrow to Å¿ee that they are Å¿o much as reputed MiniÅ¿ters; your Å¿inne to Å¿ay they are onely reputed MiniÅ¿ters for want of mens knowing better. Tell me of one man, either MiniÅ¿ter or private ChriÅ¿tian, differing from the SubÅ¿cribers onely in the point of Independency, who dares Å¿ay thus with you. If you do account your Å¿elf a MiniÅ¿ter, which way had you your ordination? Whether by that way
that the MiniÅ¿ters of London had theirs, who you Å¿ay are no MiniÅ¿ters, &c.

2. You Å¿ay, The MiniÅ¿ters have veÅ¿ted themÅ¿elves with the priviledge of the Church, of being the ground and pillar of truth. â€” The Church (as a pillar) holds forth the truth, either in a common way to all ChriÅ¿tians mutuall exhortations, profeÅ¿Å¿ion, practice, &c. or in a miniÅ¿teriall way, preaching, adminiÅ¿tration of Sacraments, &c. If you Å¿ay the MiniÅ¿ters have veÅ¿ted themÅ¿elves with the priviledge of being the pillars of truth the firÅ¿t way, 'tis ridiculouÅ¿ly falÅ¿e, profeÅ¿Å¿ion of the truth being common to every one in the Church: If you mean (as you muÅ¿t needs) that the MiniÅ¿ters have veÅ¿ted themÅ¿elves with the priviledge of pillars in the Å¿econd reÅ¿pect, 'tis odiouÅ¿ly falÅ¿e, for the Lord JeÅ¿us himÅ¿elfe and not themÅ¿elves veÅ¿ted them with the priviledge of holding forth truth by way of Office, Eph. 4.11. ChriÅ¿t gave Å¿ome PaÅ¿tors and Teachers, 1 Cor. 12.38. God hath Å¿et Å¿ome in his Church, &c. BuÅ¿ie BiÅ¿hop, pag. 3, 4.

Though no act unto which
man is enabled by God (Å¿uch as beleeving) be a foundation in that Å¿enÅ¿e in which ChriÅ¿t is, upon whom we build the hope of out Å¿alvation, to be obtained by his mediation, yet beleeving of the Scripture, as it is an aÅ¿Å¿enting to a maine and prime credendum, viz That the Scriptures are by divine inÅ¿piration, is a neceÅ¿Å¿ary foundation for other Å¿ubÅ¿equent graces that are required in the ChriÅ¿tian Religion, and without which foundation all godlineÅ¿Å¿e and Religion would in a Å¿hort time fall to the ground; no theologicall grace can be without faith; and no faith, if the authority of the Scriptures fall.
If beleeving be no foundation, why doth the ApoÅ¿tle give to faith the name of foundation, Heb. 6.1. Not laying againe the foundation of repentance and of faith, &c. Bu. BiÅ¿h. p. 9.

TheÅ¿e words, therefore queÅ¿tionleÅ¿Å¿e no writings, &c. are the concluÅ¿ion and the reÅ¿ult of your premiÅ¿Å¿es in Å¿everall long winded pages. If your concluÅ¿ion be craÅ¿ie and hereticall, your premiÅ¿Å¿es muÅ¿t needs be Å¿o too; and therefore the Å¿etting them downe could
not have helped you; and if the concluÅ¿ion be not hereticall, why do you not defend it againÅ¿t the accuÅ¿ation of the SubÅ¿cribers, which you dare not do; but only Å¿end the SubÅ¿cribers to your premiÅ¿Å¿es in the thirteenth page, leaving the poore 18. (the concluÅ¿ion) to mercy.
SuppoÅ¿e you had in the thirteenth page written the truth, therefore ought you not to be blamed for writing errours in the 18. pag. 21. Bu. BuÅ¿h.

At your command I Å¿hall conÅ¿ult the pages, wherein you would be thought to Å¿ay, The Scriptures are the word of God. In theÅ¿e pages, and pa. 17, you Å¿ay, That you grant the matter and Å¿ubÅ¿tance of the Scriptures, the gracious counÅ¿els of the Scriptures, to be the Word of God. As that ChriÅ¿t is God and man, that he dyed, that he roÅ¿e againe, &c. TheÅ¿e you Å¿ay are onely the word of God, and not the writings or written word; when you Å¿ay the matters, &c. are the Word of God, you Å¿uppoÅ¿e they Å¿hould be beleeved for Å¿uch. But upon what ground ought I to beleeve them? I hope you wil not Å¿ay, becauÅ¿e a province of London
MiniÅ¿ters Å¿aith they are to be beleeved, nor barely becauÅ¿e the Å¿pirit tels me they are to be beleeved for the Word of God, for the Å¿pirit Å¿ends me to the written Word, bids me by that to try the Å¿pirits, and tels me I muÅ¿t be leeve nothing to be from God, but what I finde written. I therefore deÅ¿ire to go to the written Word, as revealed by God, for the building my confidence upon the matters of the Scriptures (as pardon through ChriÅ¿t, &c.) but then J. Goodwin tels me, this written Word is not Gods Word. So it muÅ¿t be the word of vaine man, and Å¿o I have no more to Å¿hew for this precious truth, ChriÅ¿t dyed for loÅ¿t man, than mans word. In your alledged pages you make no diÅ¿tinction between res credenda and ratio cudendi, the matter to be beleeved, and the ground of beleeving that matter. The matters to be beleeved are the precious truths you Å¿peake of. The ground of beleeving them is the revelation of God in his written Word. The Revelation of God hath alwayes been the foundation of faith; and now this Revelation is by writing, the ground of faith is, it
is written. What courÅ¿e tooke ChriÅ¿t and his ApoÅ¿tles to prove the matters and doctrinall aÅ¿Å¿ertions which they taught but by the written Word, and when they would render them ã€ˆ in non-Latin alphabet ã€‰ , fit for belief, they ever more tell how it is written. ConÅ¿ult with the places in the Margin and you will finde that the matter, Å¿ubÅ¿tance, precious counÅ¿ell, &c. contained in the Scripture, are proved to be things to bee beleeved becauÅ¿e they are written; yeeld your Å¿elf to that evident Scripture, Joh. 20.21. TheÅ¿e things are written that ye might beleeve that JeÅ¿us is the ChriÅ¿t the Sonne of God, &c. The rativ or ground of beleeving this precious truth, That ChriÅ¿t is the Son of God, is its revelation by writing. So Act. 14.24. Rom. 15.4. Job. 5.47. If therefore you deny (as you do in terminis) the written Word to be the word of God, what formall object hath faith? i.e. to whom or what will you Å¿end me for the building my confidence upon the matters and counÅ¿els of the Scripture, &c. Touching this I added in BuÅ¿ie BiÅ¿hop the teÅ¿timonies of Tertullian, Ireneus, Aug. ChriÅ¿oÅ¿t. &c. Bu. BiÅ¿h. p. 24.

Is not every man, as a man, a debtor to God, and a creature tyed to obedience? and doth his making himÅ¿elfe inÅ¿ufficient to diÅ¿charge the debt diÅ¿charge him from payment? it would follow, that if Å¿uch impotency excuÅ¿ed from duty, and from the obligation of the the command, that thoÅ¿e men were moÅ¿t excuÅ¿able that were moÅ¿t Å¿infull, and had by long accuÅ¿toming themÅ¿elves to Å¿in, made themÅ¿elves moÅ¿t unable to leave and forÅ¿ake Å¿inne; nay, if by reaÅ¿on hereof God did not command obedience from them, it would follow, that Å¿uch did not Å¿inne at all; (for where there is no precept, there is no tranÅ¿greÅ¿Å¿ion) and Å¿o according to you, by a mans progreÅ¿Å¿e in Å¿in he Å¿hould make himÅ¿elfe ceaÅ¿e to be Å¿infull. BuÅ¿. BiÅ¿h. p. 29.
In your next, prove 1. That they who periÅ¿h have power to beleeve. The Scripture denyeth it, when it Å¿aith, The world cannot receive the Spirit, &c. Joh. 14.17.

2. Prove if a man hath not
power, that this impotency is meerely poenall, as inflicted by God, Å¿o involuntarily indured by man (for that is the nature of a puniÅ¿hment properly Å¿o called) the Scripture Å¿aith, Man hath found out many inventions, Eccl. 7. &c. Gen. 6.12. All fleÅ¿h hath corrupted its way, &c. BuÅ¿. BiÅ¿h. p. 31.

I Å¿uppoÅ¿e by your naturall man, who you Å¿ay doth things to which God hath annexed acceptation, you meane the Å¿ame man the ApoÅ¿tle Å¿peaks of, Rom. 8.8. The man in the fleÅ¿h. now, that man cannot pleaÅ¿e God, though your naturall man doth things acceptable to God. Invert not gods and Natures order. FirÅ¿t, let the tree be good, and then the fruit. BuÅ¿. BiÅ¿h. p. 34.

What Å¿tuffe is here! have all the world Å¿ufficient meanes of beleeving theÅ¿e two, 1. That God is. 2. That he is a rewarder of them that diligently Å¿eeke him? Paraeus informes you, that thoÅ¿e two heads of Å¿aith, that God is, and that God is a rewarder of them that diligently Å¿eeke him, are not to be underÅ¿tood PhiloÅ¿ophically, but Theologically; that the eternall God is Father, Sonne, and Holy GhoÅ¿t, and that be is a rewarder
of them that Å¿eeke him Evangelically by faith in ChriÅ¿t, with the benefits of the GoÅ¿pell, pardon, adoption, Å¿anctification, glory. And can heathens by the Å¿im, moone, and Å¿ â€¢ arres do this? Can they by the light of nature beleeve a trinity of perÅ¿ons in unity of eÅ¿Å¿ence. None (Å¿aith Gerrard) can be led to the knowledge of God by the creatures, but only Å¿o farre forth as God is their cauÅ¿e. Now, God is their cauÅ¿e by a divine power common to the three perÅ¿ons, therfore by the creatures we can onely attain to knowledge of theÅ¿e things which are common to the three PerÅ¿ons, and not to the knowledge of the diÅ¿tinction of PerÅ¿ons, Ger. de Trin. and can the heathens by the workes of creation have the diÅ¿covery of a Mediator, and have ChriÅ¿t made knowne to them, and beleeve in him? I am Å¿ure you nsver learned this of the ApoÅ¿tles, who Å¿aith; that faith cometh by hearing, Rom. 10. or are you of Smalcius the Socinian his judgment, who Å¿aith, that faith in ChriÅ¿t is not alwaies required to juÅ¿tification, but faith Å¿imply; and he proves it out of this very Sctipture that you have alleadged, Heb. 11.6. for the faith of heathens, &c. BuÅ¿. BiÅ¿h. p. 36.

The Fathers aÅ¿Å¿ert the being and nature of free-will only, and not its power to Å¿upernaturall good in all the paÅ¿Å¿ages which you alleadge out of them. Though AuÅ¿tin and Jerom againÅ¿t the Manichees maintained the nature of free-will, yet 'tis as true that againÅ¿t the Pelagians they denyed the abilities of free-wil to good Å¿upernaturall. Of this latter you wiÅ¿ely take no notice at all, as making directly againÅ¿t you, though there are hundreds of inÅ¿tances to that purpoÅ¿e to be found in them. And thus the learned, and orthodox Divines of the reformed Churches abroad, underÅ¿tand Austin and Hierom, when alleadged by PapiÅ¿ts and Arminians, as writing for free-will. Rivetus and Walleus, two famouÅ¿ly learned writers among the ProteÅ¿tants Å¿hall Å¿uffice for inÅ¿tances. Baily the JeÅ¿uit, objected out of Austin to prove free-will, that very place againÅ¿t the ProteÅ¿tants, which you alleadge againÅ¿t the MiniÅ¿ters. The words of AuÅ¿tine which both Baily and your Å¿elfe alleadge are theÅ¿e. Si non eÅ¿tliberum arbitrium quomodo Deus judicat mundum? If there
be no free-will how doth God judge the world? This place Rivet underÅ¿tands onely of the naturall being of free-will, For Å¿aith he, if man were turned into a Å¿tone, or a block, or a bruit creature, be Å¿hould be exempted from Gods Judgement, but Å¿ince when he acts out of deliberation be chuÅ¿eth and willeth what pleaÅ¿eth him, he deÅ¿ervedly gives account of his actions, Riv. to. 2. p. 183. The place you alleadge out of Jerom is this. FruÅ¿tra BlaÅ¿phemas & ingeris, &c. Thou blaÅ¿phemeÅ¿t in vaine, buzzing in the eares of the ignorant that we condemne freewill; And Waleus, T. 2. p. 95. anÅ¿wers Corvinus in theÅ¿e words of Hierom. FruÅ¿tra, &c. but then he gives the reaÅ¿on why, and how both be and Hierom did allow of free-will, not in regard of its abilities to good Å¿upernaturall, But becauÅ¿e (Å¿aith Waleus) He denyeth man to be created according to the Image of God, who denies him to be adorn'd with the naturall faculty of freewill. BuÅ¿. BiÅ¿h. p. 46.

In BuÅ¿. BiÅ¿h. I Å¿et downe the agreement betweene the Fathers and the SubÅ¿cribers, concerning the doctrine of the adjutory of grace at large, and
concluded thus. I Å¿hould gladly be informed by you in your next what the MiniÅ¿ters adjutorium differs from that held forth by the Fathers, and what they hold tending more toward a compulÅ¿ory then theÅ¿e Fathers here, and in hundreds of other places have written, but he anÅ¿wers nothing.

Your miÅ¿take here is pittifull, for the great queÅ¿tion between Hierom, AuguÅ¿tine, and Pelagius, was not whither the will did Å¿tand in need of the adjutory of grace for the performance of good, but what kinde of adjutory it was, of which the will did Å¿tand in need, and wherein grace was an adjutory; and I alleadge Å¿undry places to prove that Pelagius himÅ¿elfe granted the neceÅ¿Å¿ity of the adjutory, but that AuÅ¿tine was not Å¿atisfied with that his grant, Å¿aying, that Pelagius is to be askt what grace he meaneth.
TheÅ¿e are Å¿ome of the heads of thoÅ¿e many paÅ¿Å¿ages which Mr. G. toucheth not, whether becauÅ¿e they were too conÅ¿iderable, or too contemptible himÅ¿elfe beÅ¿t knowes.

Sundry other materiall omiÅ¿Å¿ions I could mention; and how unÅ¿choller-like a deportment is it for him to boaÅ¿t, that Buce and the Fathers are of his opinion, and yet when the contrary is proved, by Å¿hewing that the Å¿cope and Å¿treyne of their writings oppoÅ¿e his dotage, and how they explaine themÅ¿elves, to
have nothing to Å¿ay, but that theÅ¿e Authors contradict themÅ¿elves, and never to anÅ¿wer thoÅ¿e multitudes of places which out of the Å¿aid Authors are brought againÅ¿t him?

div.head: CHAP. III.

argument.p: Shewing the weakneÅ¿Å¿e and erroneouÅ¿neÅ¿Å¿e of his pretended anÅ¿wers to what I bring againÅ¿t his Errours about the holy Scripture.

div.p: IN your title page you Å¿ay there are two great queÅ¿tions which in your booke are Å¿atisfactorily diÅ¿cuÅ¿Å¿ed:
The one concerning the foundation of ChriÅ¿tian Religion.
The other concerning the power of the naturall man to good Å¿upernaturall.

The former whereof, you diÅ¿cuÅ¿Å¿e after a faÅ¿hion, from page the 26. to page the 38 of your Youngling Elder, concerning which your poÅ¿ition was this: QueÅ¿tionleÅ¿Å¿e no writing whatÅ¿oever, whether tranÅ¿lations or originali, is the foundation of ChriÅ¿tian Religion.

I have proved in BuÅ¿ie BiÅ¿hop that this poÅ¿ition doth raze and deÅ¿troy the very foundation of ChriÅ¿tian Religion,BuÅ¿ie BiÅ¿hop; p, 23, 24. &c. and the ground-work of faith; I Å¿till abide by what I there proved and maintained; I fear not at all to tell you, that this your aÅ¿Å¿ertion being imbraced, faith muÅ¿t needs be over throwne: That the matters and precious truths laid downe in the Scriptures; as that ChriÅ¿t is God and man, That he dyed for Å¿inners, &c. can never be beleeved with a Divine faith, unleÅ¿Å¿e the ratio credendi or ground of Å¿uch beleeving be the revelation of God in writing, or the written Word. I againe inculcate, that your blaÅ¿phemous poÅ¿ition, No writing, &c. is contrary to Scripture, which tels us, the Church is built upon the foundation of the Prophets and ApoÅ¿tles, Chamier to 1. L. 6. c. 8.
EpheÅ¿. 2.20. that is, their writings, Å¿ee Chamier who vindicateth this place againÅ¿t the exceptions of the PopiÅ¿h writers.

Your poÅ¿ition directly oppoÅ¿eth that place, Joh. 20.31. TheÅ¿e
things are written that ye might beleeve that JeÅ¿us is the ChriÅ¿t, the Sonne of God, and that beleeving ye might have life through his Name,
Deut. 17.18.19. EÅ¿a. 8.20. Ioh. 5.39. 2 Pet. 1.19. Luk. 24.25, 27, 46. Act. 13.33. Act. 17.11. Rom. 14.11. &c. and that other, 1 Joh 5.13. TheÅ¿e things have I written unto you, &c. that ye might beleeve on the Name of the Son of God; with multitudes of other places which have been, and might againe be mentioned, in all which the ground and foundation of our beleeving the truths of Å¿alvation, and conÅ¿equently of religion, is Å¿aid to be the written Word.

Nor did I ever meet with any one Orthodox Writer, but he oppugned this your abominable aÅ¿Å¿ertion, when he diÅ¿courÅ¿eth concerning the Scriptures in this point. I quoted Å¿undry places out of the Fathers in my laÅ¿t, fully to that purpoÅ¿e, out of Tertullian, Ireneus, AuguÅ¿tine, Hierome. I might adde, that all our moderne ProteÅ¿tant Writers oppoÅ¿e you herein.

To name all would require a volume. Zanchy. Tom. 8. in ConfeÅ¿Å¿. cals the Scriptures, The foundation of all ChriÅ¿tian Religion. Synops. pur. theol. diÅ¿. p. 2. The Leyden-profeÅ¿Å¿ors aÅ¿Å¿ert the Scriptures to be prineipium & fundamentum omnium ChriÅ¿tianorum dogmatum, &c. Gomarus alÅ¿o, TheÅ¿. de Å¿criptura, may be Å¿een to this purpoÅ¿e.AmeÅ¿ â€¢ medul. c. Å¿crip. Tilen Å¿yntag. diÅ¿p. de Å¿crip. Rivetus DiÅ¿p. 1. de Å¿crip. And I deÅ¿ire the Reader to conÅ¿ider, That in this whole diÅ¿courÅ¿e, though you exceed your Å¿elfe in impudence and audacious aÅ¿Å¿ertions, yet you do not Å¿o much as offer a juÅ¿tification of this TheÅ¿s, as it is Å¿et downe in the teÅ¿timony and in terminis taken out of your booke by the London MiniÅ¿ters, and therefore whatever you Å¿ay might be neglected as not appertaining to this controverÅ¿ie between you and me.
