Take away the purity of the written Word, and the purity of Doctrine taken out of the written Word (as GlaÅ¿Å¿ius Å¿aith) muÅ¿t needs fall to the ground; and what proofe can be taken out of the Scriptures againÅ¿t errours, if this be admitted the Scriptures are corrupted, as Å¿aith AuguÅ¿tine. And 5. further, prove from the falÅ¿e printing in Å¿ome Copies that therefore the Canon or written Word is depraved, Å¿hew that becauÅ¿e Å¿ome words may be written wrong, therefore the written Word of God is corrupted. CeaÅ¿eth it not Å¿o farre to be Gods Word, as any thing is printed againÅ¿t the minde of the Lord the Revealer? Is this purity of the Canon at the courteÅ¿ie of a Printers boy? Mans word may be inÅ¿erted, but Gods not by him depraved; Å¿omething may be repreÅ¿ented inÅ¿tead of the Word, but the Word is not corrupted by that miÅ¿-repreÅ¿entation. He that can make Gods Word to become his own, that is, humane & corrupt, may with the Å¿ame labour make his own word to become Gods, and of divine Authority. Nay, prove the errors of the edition (E. G. of our new TranÅ¿lation) from the errors of the Copies, learne of the more learned Chamier, PauÅ¿t. I. 12. c. 10. IpÅ¿aratio cogit ut codices diÅ¿tinguamus ab editione, haec enim proÅ¿ect a abuno principio, illi quotidie Å¿unt authoritate privatÃ¢, vel cujus libet voluntate; ergo non bene concluditur Ã Å¿ingulis codicibus adverÅ¿us primariam editionem. We cannot conclude from Å¿ome Copies againÅ¿t an edition.

p.hi: The true and proper foundation of Religion is not any thing that is viÅ¿ible,
p.label: Arg. 6
p.hi: or expoÅ¿ed to the outward Å¿ences, but Å¿omething Å¿pirituall, and opprehenÅ¿ible only by the underÅ¿tanding, &c. but Bibles, or the Scriptures are legible,

div.p:
The foundation of Religion taken materially for the truths
contained in Scripture, the things beleeved, or fundamentum fedei quod is inviÅ¿ible, and not expoÅ¿ed to outward Å¿ence, but taken formally for the fundamentum propter quod, or for which faith yeeldeth aÅ¿Å¿ent unto the matter beleeved, for as much as God worketh mediately, and now revealeth no truth to us but by externall meanes, and Divine Authority of it Å¿elfe is hidden and unknowne, the thing into which faith is ultimately reÅ¿olved muÅ¿t be Å¿omething externally knowne, which we may read or heare,
Vid. White, way to the Church, p. 378 and you muÅ¿t either yeeld an externall foundation and formall object of faith, or elÅ¿e lead us to Å¿ecret revelations.

The materiall object of faith comprehends the Articles of faith, as that God is one in eÅ¿Å¿ence, and three in perÅ¿on; that ChriÅ¿t dyed, and roÅ¿e againe the third day, &c. but the formall object of faith, or the reaÅ¿on wherefore I give aÅ¿Å¿ent unto theÅ¿e matters and Articles of faith is Authority Divine revealed in writing.

Nor 2. is your ConÅ¿equence true, viz. If any booke be the foundation, then is the foundation Å¿omewhat viÅ¿ible, &c. becauÅ¿e our diÅ¿pute is not about Inke and Paper, Bookes or words materially conÅ¿idered, which are the object of Å¿ight, but about words and bookes as they are Å¿igna conceptuum, and Å¿o diÅ¿cernable only by the underÅ¿tanding, Verbis & vocibus per Å¿e & materialiter conÅ¿ideratis nulla in eÅ¿t vis, Å¿aith Keckerman.

3. How wretchedly weak is your proofe,Yo. Eld. p. 35. that nothing externall is the foundation of faith; becauÅ¿e then (Å¿ay you) there is nothing neceÅ¿Å¿ary to be beleeved by any man to make him religious but what he Å¿ees with his eyes, &c. And (by the way) I pray anÅ¿wer; Is any thing to be beleeved to make a man religious, but what may be Å¿eene written in the Scriptures? what a diÅ¿puter rampant have we here? And you Å¿ay, every man that did but looke into â€¢ Bible, and Å¿ee Å¿uch and Å¿uch Å¿entences written or printed there, and beleeved accordingly, that theÅ¿e words and Å¿entences were here written and printed, muÅ¿t needs hereby become truly religious, &c.

Thinke you (dreadfull Sir) by Å¿uch Å¿tuffe as this to make your friend William of your judgement? though the Word written be the foundation of Religion, doth it follow that there is nothing neceÅ¿Å¿ary to be beleeved for the making of a man religious but this; to beleeve that Å¿uch and Å¿uch things are written;
is it not alÅ¿o required that a man Å¿hould beleeve the truths of the word, becauÅ¿e they are written from God as well as that he Å¿ees they are written?

The AÅ¿Å¿ent to the truth of the things written is faith, and not only that the things are written; what can you Å¿ay againÅ¿t this propoÅ¿ition, WhoÅ¿oever beleeves with his heart the things that are writen in theÅ¿e bookes, becauÅ¿e the firÅ¿t beleeves that theÅ¿e bookes in which he Å¿ees them written are the oracles of God, is truly religious.

Your Å¿eventh commodity which you cail a demonÅ¿tration,
Argm. 7 is the Å¿ame with the Å¿econd; only it containes an abÅ¿urdity or two more not worth the reciting.

Your Argument is this;Yo. Eld p. 38.
The true and proper foundation of religion is intrinÅ¿ecally, eÅ¿Å¿entially, and in the nature of it unchangeable and unalterable in the leaÅ¿t, by the wills, pleaÅ¿ures, or attempts of men; but there is no book or books whatÅ¿oever, Bible or other, but in the contents of them they may be altered and changed by men. Ergo:

It Å¿eemes you are much pleaÅ¿ed with the blaÅ¿phemy of the JeÅ¿uits againÅ¿t the Scriptures, AnÅ¿w. drawne from their corruption; your Å¿econd Argument was drawne from the periÅ¿hableneÅ¿Å¿e of them; your fifth was, they are corruptible; your Å¿eventh, they are changeable. Your major I deny not, if it only import, that the foundation of religion admits not of the leaÅ¿t change in the eÅ¿Å¿ence or nature of it by men; but if it import that it is repugnant to the nature of the foundation to be changed in the leaÅ¿t, though this change be only accidentall, I deny it.

The proofe of your major, (viz. That if the foundation of religion were intrinÅ¿ecally and in the nature of it changeable, then can it not be any matter of truth, becauÅ¿e the nature of truth is like the nature of God, unchangeable) bewrayes your ignorance, or your dotage, or Å¿omething worÅ¿e, though ordinary with you; what created veritie is there that is as unchangeable as God, and which God cannot change? Is it veritas metaphyÅ¿ica, or the truth of being? Cannot God annihilate all created beings, and if Å¿o what becomes of their verity? Is it Logicall truth, or truth of PropoÅ¿itions? Doth it not ceaÅ¿e upon the change of the Å¿ubject? JeÅ¿us ChriÅ¿t is to come in the fleÅ¿h was once a true propoÅ¿ition, and the object of the faith of thoÅ¿e that lived before ChriÅ¿t his Incarnation, but is it Å¿o Å¿till? and is not veritas ethica, or the agreement
of the judgement or minde with the propoÅ¿ition, changeable likewiÅ¿e upon the Å¿ame ground.

To your minor, whereas you alledge the changeableneÅ¿Å¿e of all Bibles in the contents of them, what meane you by contents? meane you inke, papers, letters, &c. Å¿uch changes either pervert the Å¿ence, and Å¿o farre as the Scriptures are thus chang'd they ceaÅ¿e to be the written Word, or they pervert it not,Waleus. T. 1. p. 129. Scriptura Å¿ubÅ¿tanti â€¢ non poteÅ¿t corrumpi. and if any Å¿uch changes be, they nothing hinder the written Word from being the foundation of faith. Sphalmata Typographica, Typographicall faults makeerrours in Orthography, none in Divinity.

Your laÅ¿t demonÅ¿tration; Arg. 3 Yo. Eld. p. 36.
If the Scripture be the true foundation of Religion, it muÅ¿t be underÅ¿tood either of the Scriptures as in the originall Languages only, or only as tranÅ¿lated into other Languages, or as both; but the Scriptures neither in the originall Languages, nor as tranÅ¿lated, nor as both are the foundations. Ergo:

I deny your minor, and aÅ¿Å¿ert the Scriptures as in the originals,
AnÅ¿w. and alÅ¿o as tranÅ¿lated Å¿o farre as agreeing with the originals are the foundation.

1. How prove you that the Scriptures in the originalls are not the foundation of religion? thus; If the Scriptures be the foundation as they are in the originall Bibles, then they (Å¿ay you) that underÅ¿tand not theÅ¿e Languages, as illiterate men, cannot build upon this foundation; for your unworthy Å¿coffe of the danger of my Religion, you repreÅ¿enting me as one that underÅ¿tands not the originals; you may pleaÅ¿e to know that I am not ignorant of all originals, for either concerning your Å¿coffing, or your unmannerly jeering; Mr. T. G. Å¿aid lately, that you had it from your Father (cheap enough it Å¿eemes) but to the point: This cavill is borrowed of your old MaÅ¿ters whom in this point you follow; already anÅ¿wered by Anth. Wotton, Pop. Artic. Ar. 3 p. 20. and by Baronius againÅ¿t Turnbul. de objecto formali fid. p. 44. but I anÅ¿wer:

Illiterate or unlearned men who cannot underÅ¿tand originals, AnÅ¿w. nor yet can read tranÅ¿lations, doe build nevertheleÅ¿Å¿e their Å¿aith upon the Scriptures contained in them, though mediatly, virtually, and not with that diÅ¿tinctneÅ¿Å¿e which one learned doth, the unlearned knowing not particularly in what words
the minde of God was revealed; though you call me a Novice, yet let me teach you (if at leaÅ¿t Å¿o plaine a leÅ¿Å¿on hath not hitherto been learned by you) that unto faith there is required, Principium quod, or the foundation to be beleeved; Principium propter quod, or the reaÅ¿on why men beleeve the former; and media per quae, thoÅ¿e neceÅ¿Å¿ary meanes by which they come to beleeve, and theÅ¿e are externall, the miniÅ¿tery of the Word, and internall, the witneÅ¿Å¿e and effectuall working of the holy GhoÅ¿t, by which the heart is enabled to cloÅ¿e with the formall object of faith, viz. the revelation of Gods will in writing. Now the MiniÅ¿try of the Word and Spirit are limited to the written Word; theÅ¿e teach no other things than God hath revealed therein, and perÅ¿wade not men, but God (as the ApoÅ¿tle Å¿aith, Gal. 1.10.) Å¿o that theÅ¿e lead the moÅ¿t illiterate to the Scriptures, and are Å¿o adminiÅ¿tred that they draw the heart even of Å¿uch to aÅ¿Å¿ent to the written Word, as that into which their faith is ultimately reÅ¿olved, as the Scriptures abundantly teÅ¿tifie; and you can no more conclude from the Å¿trangeneÅ¿Å¿e of the originall Languages to thoÅ¿e that are illiterate, that illiterate perÅ¿ons doe not build their faith upon the written Word contained in them, than that one who only underÅ¿tands the EngliÅ¿h tongue and receives a Letter from his Father in the French tongue (for the explaining whereof, the Father hath appointed an Interpreter) builds not his obedience ultimately upon the writing of his Father, though in a Å¿trange tongue.

2. You endeavour to prove that the Scriptures are not the foundation of Religion, as in TranÅ¿lations and Originalls, thus; If they be this foundation in both thoÅ¿e conÅ¿iderations, or as well in the one or the other, then two things or more, Å¿pecifically differing one from another, may notwithÅ¿tanding be one and the Å¿ame numeriall thing,

You Å¿hould rather have laid your conÅ¿equence thus, AnÅ¿w.
then ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ Å¿ubject numerically the Å¿ame may be the Å¿ubject of accidents Å¿pecifically different; but you tell me of two Å¿uppoÅ¿itions upon which your conÅ¿equence Å¿tands.
1. That the foundation of Religion is but one and the Å¿ame numerically.
2. That the Scriptures in Å¿everall Languages differ Å¿pecifically among themÅ¿elues.

About the identy of the foundation numerically, I Å¿hall not contend; but how prove you your Å¿econd Å¿uppoÅ¿ition? viz. That the Scriptures in Å¿everall Languages differ Å¿pecifically, you indeavour it thus:

Two things (you Å¿ay) which differ more than numerically, differ Å¿pecifically; Now an Hebrew and a SpaniÅ¿h Bible, differ more than numerically, becauÅ¿e they differ more than two SpaniÅ¿h or two Hebrew Bibles differ from one another, and yet theÅ¿e differ numerically the one from the other.

1. Had the Youngling Elder diÅ¿puted thus, how many exclamations, of poore man! illiterate Å¿oule! Å¿illy man! &c. would your tender heart have beÅ¿towed upon him; but I Å¿hall not retaliate, for the Reader (if intelligent) I am confident will Å¿pare me a labour. Things (you Å¿ay) that differ plusquam numero, do differ Å¿pecie. Should a freÅ¿h-man hear you reaÅ¿on thus. Mas & faemina differunt pluÅ¿quam numero, ergo differunt Å¿pecie, or a learned man and an ideot, differunt pluÅ¿quam numero ergo differunt Å¿pecie, they would laugh at your argument; the very boyes would judge you a profeÅ¿Å¿or fitter for an alley than an Academye. Do not you grant that theÅ¿e differ Å¿pecie accidentali onely; and will you conclude that therefore they differ Å¿pecifically.

2. You Å¿ay, That though the difference betweene an Hebrew Bible and a SpaniÅ¿h is but in Å¿pecie accidentali, or Å¿pecificall accidentall, yet Å¿uch a difference as this is Å¿ufficient to prove that they differ numerically. You give in already, and Å¿hew your Å¿elf but a founder'd diÅ¿putant, for what is this to your undertaking, which was to prove your Å¿econd Å¿uppoÅ¿ition, viz. That they do differ Å¿pecifically and not numerically onely, which was nothing to the Å¿econd Å¿uppoÅ¿ition, page 37.

3. You contend that a SpaniÅ¿h Bible, a Latine, and an EngliÅ¿h, differ in Å¿pecie accidentali, or with a difference Å¿pecifical accidentall in regard of the Å¿pecifically different Languages wherein they were written. Ergo quid, how by all this prove you your aÅ¿Å¿ertion, which was; that the Å¿criptures in their Å¿everall Languages do differ Å¿pecifically; nay how prove you by the Å¿pecifical accidental d â€¢ fference of the Bibles, that the Scripture or the foundation is not the Å¿ame numerically. The Languages I will grant differ Å¿pecifically, and the copies doe differ with a difference Å¿pecificall accidentall, but
the Scripture the foundation of faith, the will of God revesled in writing, is numerically and identically the Å¿ame. May not the Å¿ame thing numerically be the Å¿ubject of accidents Å¿pecifically different? The Å¿ame man may (I Å¿peak not of MaÅ¿ter Goodwin) Å¿peake Latine, Greek, and Hebrew. TheÅ¿e Languages differ Å¿pecifically, yet the man who Å¿peaks them, is not multiplyed, but is numerically the Å¿ame. EÅ¿th. 3.12.8, 9. AhaÅ¿huerus Å¿ent out a decree to the people of an hundred twenty and Å¿even Provinces in Å¿evecall Languages, the Decree was one numerically, for he Å¿ent not out many but onely one Decree, though the Languages differed Å¿pecifically, and the Copies numerically, and Å¿pecie accidentali, in regard of the Å¿pecifically different Languages; and why may not the Å¿ame be Å¿aid of the foundation of Religion. The Bibles and Copies wherein the foundation of Religion is contained differ Å¿pecifically accidentally, in regard of their Å¿pecifically different Languages, but the foundation of Religion, i. e. the revelation of the will of God in writing is numerically one and the Å¿ame; Å¿o that your learned argument, That the Scriptures cannot be the foundation of Religion in Å¿everall Languages, becauÅ¿e of the Å¿pecificall or at leaÅ¿t numericall difference of the Bibles, is vaine and childiÅ¿h.

We have Å¿een your acumen in arguing, let us Å¿ee what you can do in anÅ¿wering (Å¿o far as you go) of what you are pleaÅ¿ed to pick out of BuÅ¿ie BiÅ¿hop, againÅ¿t your opinion concerning the Scriptures.

You Å¿ay but very little by way of anÅ¿wer; but in that little you wofully trifle; you Å¿tay not to anÅ¿wer the Scriptures I bring againÅ¿t you at all, nor do Å¿eriouÅ¿ly indeavour Å¿atisfaction in any thing, onely you propound two or three Å¿light and impertinent quaeries againÅ¿t what I write, and Å¿o, as if you were lapping at Nilus, you haÅ¿tily and Å¿uperficially conclude.

I askt you in the BuÅ¿ie BiÅ¿hop, BuÅ¿ie BiÅ¿hop; p. 22. how any could beleeve the matter and Å¿ubÅ¿tance of the Scriptures to be the Word of God, when as he must be uncertaine whether the written Word wherein the matter is contained, is the Word of God or no?
To this you anÅ¿wer by propounding theÅ¿e ignorant demands, whereof the firÅ¿t hath two branches.Yo. Eld. p. 39. &c.

1. Is not this a queÅ¿tion of the Å¿ame profound calculation with this, how can a man beleeve the Å¿un is a greater and the moone a leÅ¿Å¿er light if he be uncertaine whether every jot and tittle of what is read in
our Bible, Gen. 1.16. be the Word of God or no? becauÅ¿e here it is Å¿aid, And God made two great lights, the greater, &c.

2. And afterwards. Do not the Scriptures affirme, That the heavens declare the glory of God, &c. and againe, That that which may be knowne of God, his inviÅ¿ible things, his eternall power and Godhead, are clearely Å¿eene from the creation of the world; and that the Gentiles (without the written Word) Å¿hew the works of the Law written in their hearts?

In this demand which you put under two diÅ¿tinct heads, you expreÅ¿Å¿e two groÅ¿Å¿e miÅ¿takes, unworthy a Å¿choller,
AnÅ¿w. though not unbeÅ¿eeming your Å¿elf.

1. In that you diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h not betweene the matters of the Scripture to be beleeved, i. e. betweene thoÅ¿e things or objects which are communia, Å¿uch as may be knowe by the light of nature, and thoÅ¿e which are propria, Å¿uch as cannot be knowne but by the Revelation of the written Word; our queÅ¿tion was not concerning winter and Å¿ummer, the greatneÅ¿Å¿e of the Sun and Moon, &c. but concerning the MyÅ¿teries of faith.

For when you explaine your Å¿elf Sion Coll. viÅ¿ited, and Divine Auth. pag. 17. what you meant by the matter, Å¿ubÅ¿tance, precious counÅ¿els of the Scripture, did you make any mention of the Å¿un and moone, the winter and Å¿ummer; did you not Å¿ay you meant Å¿uch truths as theÅ¿e? That ChriÅ¿t was God and man, That ChriÅ¿t dyed, That he aroÅ¿e againe, &c. Now can you know theÅ¿e without a written Word, though you may the greatneÅ¿Å¿e of the Å¿un above that of the Moone?

Your Å¿econd groÅ¿Å¿e miÅ¿take in propounding this demand, is, in that you diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h not betweene an intellectuall habit, knowledge, and a divine grace, faith; the ground of the one being reaÅ¿on, the ground of the other being divine teÅ¿timony. Or in that you diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿h not between fides divina, or theologica, and fides naturalis & acquiÅ¿ita, acquired by humane reaÅ¿ons, or by the authority of man; it was of the former that I diÅ¿puted, and now you learnedly (ut Å¿oles) fly to the latter. When you Å¿ay, That without the written Word you can beleeve the greatneÅ¿Å¿e of the Sun above that of the Moon, Can you beleeve this with a divine faith, without a written Word? Quaevis propoÅ¿itio phyÅ¿ica, aÅ¿trologica, hiÅ¿torica fit objectum fidei, Å¿i Ã deo in Scripturis nobis propanatur,
Davevant, p. 12.Scriptura, & fides noÅ¿tra Å¿unt aequalis latitudinis, fides nec plus nec minus debet amplecti quÃ m eÅ¿t in Scriptura revelatum. Geth. Exeg. p. 169.
de judice fidei, Then (Å¿aith he) is any PhyÅ¿icall, AÅ¿trologicall, HiÅ¿toricall propoÅ¿ition, the object of faith when it is propounded to us by God in the Scriptures; and page 149. Formalis ratio credendi, eÅ¿t authoritas dei revelantis. You may alÅ¿o Å¿ay, That without a written Word you beleeve that the worlds were framed by God, but can you beleeve this with a divine faith, unleÅ¿Å¿e you had a written word for it? TheÅ¿e things haply you may know, and by a naturall or acquired faith, but not by a divine faith, beleeve, unleÅ¿Å¿e written, quod non lego, non credo.

Your Å¿econd profound demand is: If it be impoÅ¿Å¿ible for me to beleeve that the matter and Å¿ubÅ¿tance of the Scripture is the Word of God, becauÅ¿e I am uncertaine whether the written Word be the word of God or no, how came the Patriarchs to beleeve it, who lived the firÅ¿t two thouÅ¿and yeeres of the world, Å¿ince it was uncertaine to them whether the word Å¿hould ever be written? The Å¿ame way to bring me to beleeve what they believed is open to the glorious God.

ThoÅ¿e things that the Patriarchs beleeved, AnÅ¿w. they had from and by divine revelation, and though the written word was not needfull to them for the grounding their faith upon the things beleeved, God then immediately manifeÅ¿ting himÅ¿elfe to them without it, as even now I told you, yet the like cannot be Å¿aid of us who live under a different diÅ¿penÅ¿ation. Vid. Riv. Cath. Orth. T. 1. Q. 1. VVhitak. Chamier, &c.

This was the Å¿ubÅ¿tance of your firÅ¿t argument, Yo. Eld. p. 32. I muÅ¿t Å¿end you back for anÅ¿wer: The Å¿ame way to bring you to beleeve, may be open by Gods power, but it is not his pleaÅ¿ure to open it.

3. You Å¿ay, The nature, beauty, worth, weight, &c. of the matters and Å¿ubÅ¿tance of the Scripture is Å¿ufficient to bring men to believe that they are things which came from God, though they had not the Å¿uper-added advantage of any thing in the Scripture as writing.

It was great pitty that you were not conÅ¿ulted withall to give your judgement concerning the moÅ¿t advantagious way of bringing men to believe; AnÅ¿w. why inÅ¿tead of inventing new grounds of faith, Å¿ubmit you not to the old? Its no matter what Å¿uch a poore creature as your Å¿elf Å¿ay, when you tell us what is the moÅ¿t Å¿ufficient way to bring men to beleeve, when as I Å¿ee that the
wiÅ¿e God was pleaÅ¿ed not onely to have the matters committed to writing, but alÅ¿o to tell us (notwithÅ¿tanding the weight of the matter) that the end of that writing was that men might beleeve thoÅ¿e matters, TheÅ¿e things are written that ye might beleeve, Job. 21. and 1 Jo. 5.13. why rather did not the EvangeliÅ¿t Å¿ay, TheÅ¿e things are Å¿o weighty, Å¿o worthy, Å¿o beautifull, that therefore you have reaÅ¿on to beleeve them.

2. The moÅ¿t weighty worthy matter that ever was beleeved, had it onely been beleeved for its owne weight and worth, and not as revealed by God, and becauÅ¿e God manifeÅ¿ted it, had not been beleeved with a divine faith. 'Tis not the worth of the thing but the Authority of the Speaker that is the ground of a mans faith: Nor doe I underÅ¿tand how the worth and beauty of any thing can be Å¿aid to bring men to beleeve that thing, they may indeed bring a man to deÅ¿ire it, and to long to enjoy it; there's required to faith not a worth and a beauty in the thing revealed, but truth ln the revelatien; the object of aÅ¿Å¿ent is not pulchrum; but verum, not the beauty of the thing Å¿poken, but the veracity of the Å¿peaker. Be the thing never Å¿o good, yet I beleeve not (Å¿aith learned Downame) unleÅ¿Å¿e I be perÅ¿waded it is true, p. 355. Treat. of juÅ¿tification.

3. He that aÅ¿Å¿ents not to the Scriptures as revealed by God, cannot aÅ¿Å¿ent unto the beauty of the matters contained in the Scriptures. There's nothing revealed in the Scripture will Å¿eeme truly beautifull and worthy to that man that beleeves not the authority of the Revealer. If the written word be entertained, and received as (Å¿aith the apoÅ¿tle) as the word of man, the moÅ¿t beautifull and worthy matters in the Scripture will be Å¿o far from being beleeved, that they will be profanely neglected. When as the excellenteÅ¿t matters were preached to the Jewes by ChriÅ¿t, how were they contemned, in regard that they were not lookt upon as the minde of God, but rather on the contrary.

To conclude my AnÅ¿wer to this profane conceit of yours, Å¿hould this beauty, worth, weight, &c. of the matters contained in the Scripture be admitted as the ground of beleeving them, I would know by what rule we Å¿hould judge of this their beauty, worth, weight, &c. or what it is when their beauty is impugned by hereticks (as you know that the gloriouÅ¿ly beautifull truth of
the Å¿atisfaction of ChriÅ¿t, Å¿o beautifull that its worthy of all acceptation, is by Socinus accounted the moÅ¿t deformed and unrighteous conceit that can be. What is it (I Å¿ay) in Å¿uch caÅ¿es by which I Å¿hould groundedly account the truth of God beautifull? you muÅ¿t here denying the written Word, make any mans judgement and reaÅ¿on to be the rule of the beauty and worth of the matters of the Scriptures, every one muÅ¿t eÅ¿teeme of truth, and believe them, as reaÅ¿on dictates and tels them they are beautifull, and then Mr. Goodwins Socinian deÅ¿igne is perfectly accompliÅ¿ht. And there are who Å¿tick not to Å¿ay, That all the clamourous outcries of your tongue and pen intend nothing but the advancing the Diana of recta ratio inÅ¿tead of Scripture.

Yet againe you querie (though to no purpoÅ¿e,Yo. Eld. p. 40. yet) to this effect: Doth not (Å¿ay you) the Scripture affirme that the ã€ˆ in non-Latin alphabet ã€‰ , the goodneÅ¿Å¿e of God leadeth to repentance? Rom. 2.4. Which repentance cannot be without beleeving of the matters of the Scripture, as that upon repentance God will be gracious and accept men into favour, and forgive their Å¿innes; now this goodneÅ¿Å¿e of God, leading to this repentance, is extended to many, who are uncertaine whether the written word be the Word of God or no.

1. AnÅ¿w. This is a paÅ¿Å¿age of the Å¿ame prophane calculation with that in Divine Auth. where you Å¿aid, pag. 182. That the Heathens who only have the Heavens, the Sun, Moon, and Stars, to preach the GoÅ¿pell unto them, have reaÅ¿on Å¿ufficient to judge the Å¿ame judgement with them who have the Letter of the GoÅ¿pell. Which in BuÅ¿ie BiÅ¿hop was diÅ¿proved; to which in this booke you reply nothing, but new braze your face and Å¿ay the Å¿ame things againe.

2. From this place Rom. 2.4. that Gods goodneÅ¿Å¿e leads to repentance, followes it that Heathens who onely were invited by the generall goodneÅ¿Å¿e of God in the governing of the world, beleeved that God would be gracious unto them,Spanhem de grat. univerÅ¿. pag. 1291. and forgive them their Å¿innes in ChriÅ¿t the Mediator? followes it that all invitation to repentance is invitation to a Redeemer, and to beleeving, and that rain from Heaven and fruitfull Å¿eaÅ¿ons did afford Å¿uch an invitation? hard to the carnall careleÅ¿Å¿e man, yet (as Salmon Å¿aith of knowledge Prov. 146.) faith is eaÅ¿ie to him that will believe, not that it is Å¿imply in mans power, but that GODS SPIRIT SO OPENETH HIS UNDERSTANDING, &c.

div.head: The Div. Auth. of the Scriptures.
div.p:
Pag 26. Naturall men may do Å¿uch things, as whereunto God hath by way of promiÅ¿e
annexed grace and acceptation.

Page 169. To Å¿uppoÅ¿e that they to whom God maketh rich and Å¿weet applications of himÅ¿elfe, are wholly deÅ¿titute of all power to do what he requires of them, in this caÅ¿e to Å¿ave them from deÅ¿truction, and to confer the great things promiÅ¿ed upon them, as viz. to believe and repent, is to repreÅ¿ent the glorious God in his greateÅ¿t expreÅ¿Å¿ions of mercy and grace, and love unto the world, rather as laughing the world to Å¿corne in that great miÅ¿ery wherein it is plunged, then as a God any wayes truly deÅ¿irous, or intending to relieve it.

Page 183. They which are without (I meane without the GoÅ¿pell written or preached upon Å¿uch termes as it is preached among us daily) have alÅ¿o Å¿ufficient meanes (if not large and plentifull) for beleeving.
Page 186. They who are deÅ¿troyed and periÅ¿h by the hand of God for unbelief, had meanes, and thoÅ¿e Å¿ufficient whereby to have beleeved.

Page 182. Concerning thoÅ¿e
have onely the Heavens, the Sun, Moon, and Stars, and the goodneÅ¿Å¿e of God in the government of the world, to preach the GoÅ¿pell unto them; theÅ¿e alÅ¿o have reaÅ¿on Å¿ufficient (if not in abundance) to thinke the Å¿ame though, and judge the Å¿ame judgement with the other [who have the Letter of the GoÅ¿pell] in the point in hand.

In all the paÅ¿Å¿ages que â€¢ ed out of the whole Armour of God, there is no Å¿entence that implyeth, that naturall men may do Å¿uch things as whereunto God hath by way of promiÅ¿e annexed grace and acceptation. Men are there incited to do what lieth in them for attaining grace; but it is not Å¿aid, that any promiÅ¿e of grace is annexed to that which they do, while they temaine in their naturall eÅ¿tate.

Neither is it Å¿aid in any of thoÅ¿e paÅ¿Å¿ages, That none of thoÅ¿e to whom God maketh rich and Å¿weet applications of himÅ¿elfe, are wholly deÅ¿titute of all power to believe and repent; for thoÅ¿e Å¿weet applications in the outward diÅ¿penÅ¿ation of the Word, are made to all preÅ¿ent, though there may be many reprobates there, who have not power to believe and repent.

Nor yet is it there Å¿aid, That they who are without the
GoÅ¿pell have Å¿ufficient meanes for beleeving; nor, That they who periÅ¿h for unbeliefe, had meanes Å¿ufficient to have beleeved, if meanes be taken for that power and ability which is in a naturall man.

1 Object. If mens coming Å¿hort of that which they might have done be the reaÅ¿on of their condemnation, it undeniably followes,Yo. Eld. p. 70. that they have power to do that whereby their condemnation might be prevented.

AnÅ¿w. It doth not follow; becauÅ¿e they might more improve their naturall parts than they do, and yet not prevent condemnation thereby, they are Å¿upernaturall gifts whereby condemnation is prevented.
2 Object. In Å¿aying unbeliefe is in a mans power, Ibid. doth he not imply, that a man hath power over it, and may diÅ¿Å¿olve, Å¿ubdue, and deÅ¿troy it, if he will?

AnÅ¿w. No, he implyeth no Å¿uch thing; he onely intendeth that it ariÅ¿eth from a mans Å¿elfe, and is ordered by a mans own free will, as other corrupt acts are. The evils which are in the Devill, are in his power; yet can he not diÅ¿Å¿olve, Å¿ubdue, and deÅ¿troy them. As for the inÅ¿tances of originall corruption, blindneÅ¿Å¿e by birth, frailty of life, mortality, corruptibleneÅ¿Å¿e of fleÅ¿h, ã€ˆ in non-Latin alphabet ã€‰ , for none of theÅ¿e are acts under the will of man, to be ordered thereby, as unbeliefe is.
3 Object. QueÅ¿tionleÅ¿Å¿e a Teacher would not incourage men,Ibid. pag. 71. or perÅ¿wade men to incourage themÅ¿elves, to do that which he judgeth impoÅ¿Å¿ible for them to do.
AnÅ¿w. 1. That which is here taken to be unpoÅ¿Å¿ible, is brought upon man by his owne default.

2. It is Å¿uch an impoÅ¿Å¿ibility as God by the worke of his Spirit can, and ordinarily doth make poÅ¿Å¿ible. In this reÅ¿pect ChriÅ¿t Å¿aith of that which is impoÅ¿Å¿ible with men, that it is not Å¿o with God, Mark 10.27.
3. The Teacher doth incourage men to go as far as they can, and to do as much as in their power lyeth, to obtaine Å¿uch or Å¿uch a bleÅ¿Å¿ing; which is not to perÅ¿wade to that which is impoÅ¿Å¿ible.

4. Object. If God excludeth none [from bleeving] then hath he not inflicted any Å¿uch puniÅ¿hment upon men for their Å¿inne
in Adam, by which they are diÅ¿abled from believing.

AnÅ¿w. That which is Å¿poken of Gods excluding none, is meant of the manner of diÅ¿penÅ¿ing the GoÅ¿pell, and offering grace, which is wi â€¢â€¢ Å¿uch generall tearmes, as therein no man hath cauÅ¿e to thinke himÅ¿elfe excluded. The Author of the
ã€ˆâ€¦ã€‰ God, thus explaineth his owne minde, pag. 603. This Do â€¢ trine is to be underÅ¿tood of Gods outward diÅ¿penÅ¿ation and manife â€¢ ation of his mercy by the miniÅ¿try of the Word, wherein no difference is made betwixt perÅ¿ons, nor excertion of any. So as it calleth not into queÅ¿tion the Å¿ecret counÅ¿ell and â€¢ ernall decree of God.

body.p:
YOu,MaÅ¿ter Sou â€¢
â€¢â€¢
Vindication. with many other MiniÅ¿ters of the Province of London, gave ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ againÅ¿t this tenent of MaÅ¿ter John Goodwin, viz. touching
ã€ˆâ€¦ã€‰
aÅ¿Å¿erte â€¢ , That by impr â€¢ vement of nature a man may attaine to Å¿uch ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ , is upon which Å¿aving converÅ¿ion alwayes follows: This I judge to be an errour.1 Cor. 2.14. For the ApoÅ¿tle Å¿aith, The naturall man reiciveth not the things of the Spirit of God, for they are ã€ˆâ€¦ã€‰ him: Neither can be kn â€¢ w them, becauÅ¿e they are Å¿piritual â€¢ y ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ .
Rom. 8.5, 7, 8. And he Å¿aith alÅ¿o, They that are after the fleÅ¿h (as all naturall men are) Å¿av â€¢ ur or minde the things of the faÅ¿ â€¢ . And againe, The carnall minde is enmity againÅ¿t God, for it is not Å¿ubject to the Law of God, nor indeed can be. So that they that are in the fleÅ¿h cannot pleaÅ¿e God. Wherefore man by no naturall power can improve the gifts of nature Å¿o, as without Å¿peciall grace to will or do that which is Å¿pirituall and Å¿upernaturall, as to repent, believe, &c.

I fi â€¢ de that MaÅ¿ter John Goodwin hath alleadged Å¿ome paÅ¿Å¿ages in my booke,ChriÅ¿tians daily walk, cap 15. Å¿ect. 1. page 452, 453. as if I did concurre with him, or favour his opinion. I have hereupon conÅ¿idered and weighed well what I have there written, and finde nothing tending to the maintenance of his errour; but Å¿omething expreÅ¿ly againÅ¿t free will to good. I declaring, That notwithÅ¿tanding ChriÅ¿t may be Å¿aid to give himÅ¿elfe a ranÅ¿ome for all, &c. yet this doth not argue univerÅ¿all Redemption, nor that all men may be Å¿aved if they will. I appeale to any judicious and impartiall
Reader, whether in any thing I have there written, I have juÅ¿tified his opinion; which I am utterly againÅ¿t.

Unde â€¢ Å¿tanding of your purpoÅ¿e to returne an anÅ¿wer to MaÅ¿ter John Goodwins booke,MaÅ¿ter Calamy his Vindication. and finding that therein I am brought upon the Å¿tage as one that, in a Sermon preached Jan. 12.1644. Å¿hould Å¿ay Å¿omething to countenance that heterodox opinion of his, That a naturall man hath power to believe and repent. I thought it my duty, Å¿o far at leaÅ¿t to vindicate my Å¿elfe and my MiniÅ¿try, as to intreate you to inÅ¿ert in your AnÅ¿wer thus much as from me, by way of reply.

1. That I do and alwaies did abhorre that proud, Pelagian, and Arminian Tenent. And that 1. becauÅ¿e it Å¿eemes to me, as it is defended by him in his booke, to Å¿et up free will, (which by the fall of Adam is no longer liberum but Å¿ervum arbitrium) in the place of free grace. And to make free will to put the difference betweene the Elect and the Reprobate, and not free grace, which is coutrary to Rom. 9.11, 18. Eph. 1.5, 11. 1 Tit. 1.9.

2. BecauÅ¿e it makes a man able by nature to do Å¿omething that will poÅ¿itively and infallibly diÅ¿poÅ¿e and prepare him to converÅ¿ion, which is contrary to Rom. 11.35. John 15.5. John 6.44. And contrary to right reaÅ¿on alÅ¿o, asN â€¢ lil Å¿e diÅ¿ponit ad gradum altiorem quam habet natura. Atqui gra
â€¢ ia regenerans excedit totam naturem, quicquid igitur eÅ¿t Ã viribus naturae id inferioris eÅ¿t ordinis & improportionatum ad gratiam. PoteÅ¿t quidem homo minus peccando, mi â€¢ us indiÅ¿poÅ¿itus reddi ad recipiendam gratiam, quam alius Å¿ed nihil tamen facere poteÅ¿t, per quod ad gratiam diÅ¿ponatur. VoÅ¿Å¿i hiÅ¿toria Pelagiana. lib. 4. part. 1. & pag. 420. pag. 419. DiÅ¿poÅ¿itio ad gratiam eÅ¿t pars converfionis noÅ¿tr â€¢ : ConverÅ¿io autem eÅ¿t opus Divinwn, PÅ¿al. 85.5. Lam. 5.21.
VoÅ¿Å¿ius excellently Å¿heweth.

3. BecauÅ¿e his opinion, as he defends it, Å¿eems to me wholly to take away the neceÅ¿Å¿ity of preventing grace, and to make the grace of converÅ¿ion to be Å¿ubÅ¿equent onely to mans naturall endeavours, or at leaÅ¿t but concomitant. Which is contrary to IÅ¿a. 65.5. Rom. 9.16.

4. BecauÅ¿e the Scripture Å¿ets out the ã€ˆ in non-Latin alphabet ã€‰ and inability of anaturall man to beleeve, and repent in Å¿uch full and expreÅ¿Å¿e
termes, as that (as I conceive) it is impoÅ¿Å¿ible to be my opinion without wreÅ¿ting the Scriptures. WitneÅ¿Å¿e Gen. 6.5. Gen 8.21. Jer. 17.9. Eccl. 36.26. Mat. 7.18. John 5.25. Rom 8.7. Rom. 5.6, 10. 1 Cor. 2.14. 2 Cor. 3.5. EpheÅ¿. 2.1, 2, 3, Col. 2.13. John 3.6. and divers others of the like nature. The Scripture doth not onely Å¿ay, That a man by nature is in the darke, (as MaÅ¿ter G. erroneouÅ¿ly affirmes) but that he is darkneÅ¿Å¿e, Eph. 5.8. not onely that he wants light, but that he wants eyes alÅ¿o, Deut. 29.4. Not onely that he is de ad in Å¿innes, in regard of the guilt of Å¿inne, (as MaÅ¿ter G. Å¿aith) but alÅ¿o in regard of all Å¿pirituall ability to raiÅ¿e himÅ¿elfe, as appeareth by the next argument.

5. BecauÅ¿e converÅ¿ion in Scripture is not onely Å¿aid to be a giving of light to one that hath eyes before (is MaÅ¿ter G. Å¿aith) but a giving of Å¿ight alÅ¿o, IÅ¿a. 42.7. Lu. 4.18. It is not onely a giving an immediate actuall or preÅ¿ent capacity (as Mr. G. minceth it contrary to Scripture) but it is a Å¿utting within us a principle of Å¿pirituall life. It is not onely a raiÅ¿ â€¢ ng us up from the guilt of Å¿inne, but it is a beÅ¿towing upon us a new heart, and a new Spirit, it is a Å¿pirituall reÅ¿urrection and regeneration, 1 Pet. 1.23. Ja. 1.1 â€¢ . John 3.3. Ezek. 36.26. And therefore as a naturall man cannot contribute any thing to his naturall being, no more can he contribute any thing properly to his Å¿upernaturall being.
TheÅ¿e and divers other reaÅ¿ons have induced me alwaies Å¿ince I knew what belonged to Divinity, to deteÅ¿t and abhorre this his unÅ¿ound and unjuÅ¿tifiable opinion.
There is a Å¿econd thing that I would have you likewiÅ¿e to put into your AnÅ¿wer.

Secondly, That I am much wronged and abuÅ¿ed in what MaÅ¿ter G. relates concerning the Sermon I preached Jan. 12.1644. The truth is, looking over my notes, I finde that I made two Sermons upon the Doctrine mentioned in the Booke. In which I laid downe this poÅ¿ition quite contrary to his aÅ¿Å¿ertion, That man by nature is dead in Å¿in and treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿es, unable to do any thing that is Å¿piritually good, as he ought to do. That man by nature is unable to believe and repent, and is like the cold earth, able of it Å¿elfe to bring forth briers and thornes, but not able to do any thing pleaÅ¿ing to God, in order to eternall life, unleÅ¿Å¿e he be enabled by the Å¿eed of grace Å¿orcen in his heart by Gods holy Spirit. Indeed I added,

That a man unconverted, remaining unconverted, might do that that was right in the Å¿ight of the Lord, he might do bonum though not benÃ¨. And by the helpe of the Holy GhoÅ¿t in the common worke of it, he might do many things in order to Å¿alvation. And that the reaÅ¿on why he is damned, is not for want of power, but for not improving the power he hath; not for cannot, but will not.
But then I Å¿ubjoyned two other poÅ¿itions.
1. That no unconverted man did ever improve the power that God hath given him, but doth give advantage to God to damne him for voluntary refuÅ¿ing to do what he hath power to do.

2. That though an unconverted man did improve his naturall abilities to the utmoÅ¿t of his power, yet notwithÅ¿tanding God was not bound by any promiÅ¿e to beÅ¿tow the grace of converÅ¿ion upon him. This I proved by five arguments too long here to repeat.

And thus I have given you a Å¿hort account of what concerns me in his Booke. I have but a word more to Å¿ay; and that is to a paÅ¿Å¿age in the 131 page, in which he Å¿aith, He will not Å¿o far abuÅ¿e me, as to call me either learned or pious. For my part, I thanke God I am not Å¿olicitous what he or his Pulpit-Incendiary Å¿ay of me. I have learned of my great MaÅ¿ter to requite good for evill, and to heape coales of fire upon their heads, which I deÅ¿ire may be in remedium, not in ruinam. The great God guide us all into the wayes of peace, truth and holineÅ¿Å¿e. So prayeth

div.p: What a vaÅ¿t Ocean of Å¿corns, jeers, vilifyings, childiÅ¿h ventoÅ¿ities, and prophane puffs of wit do I Å¿ayle through, before I can eÅ¿py the leaÅ¿t point or Å¿pot of land, any thing wherein he Å¿o much as pretends to theologicall argumentation? Å¿ollid matter lodgeth in his great booke of words, as a childe of two dayes old in the great bed of Ware. Going over many pages fill'd with nothing but with Å¿cum and Å¿currility, he vents, among hundreds of other Å¿uch unÅ¿avoury paÅ¿Å¿ages, this gentle expreÅ¿Å¿ion:

Sect. 90.Yo. Eld. p. 85. Sect 90.
Confident I am, that there ã€ˆ in non-Latin alphabet ã€‰ was a g â€¢ neration of
ChriÅ¿tians (Å¿carce of men) Å¿o bloody in aÅ¿Å¿erting their opinions, &c. as the greateÅ¿t part of the London SubÅ¿cripturients.

Fo â€¢ the bloody aÅ¿Å¿erting, &c. never were the veines of any writings Å¿o fill'd with the blood which you Å¿peake of, as thoÅ¿e of this laÅ¿t and worÅ¿t of your pamphlets; certainly when you wrote it, you were under a quatidian fury, or Å¿ick of the miÅ¿erere mei; the Reader beholds you vomiting your excrements of Å¿currility and wrath in every page; what is there that you mention through your booke (if you would have it help you) but either you feigne it your friend, or elÅ¿e you frowne upon it, that it may not dare to be your enemy, the Scriptures, the Fathers, your mother Tongue, your oppoÅ¿ites, againÅ¿t their bent and mindes, are threatned unleÅ¿Å¿e they Å¿toop to your Å¿ence and Å¿ervice; Scriptures muÅ¿t Å¿peake for you againÅ¿t themÅ¿elves, and Æ²rijab-like muÅ¿t carry letters for their owne deÅ¿truction; Bucer, Ball, the Father, under the paine of Å¿elf-contradiction, and of being accounted naked and unÅ¿table, muÅ¿t turn Pelagians. Yo. Eld. p. 5. p. 76, 79.

If you will have it Å¿o, it muÅ¿t be Å¿ence for the garment to be clothed with the man, and it muÅ¿t be as proper to Å¿ay, exchange this thing into another, as to Å¿ay exchange it for another thing. Who ever will lift up a pen againÅ¿t you, muÅ¿t expect no other guerden, but to have your pen caÅ¿ed in his heart, and to lye bleeding at the feet of your writings; the pulling downe of Sion Coll â€¢ dge Å¿hall be voted the taking away of the pillar of all impiety and oppoÅ¿ition to the truth; all the workes that ever Å¿tood it out againÅ¿t you muÅ¿t be demoliÅ¿ht and diÅ¿mantled: Your next wrath is expected againÅ¿t thoÅ¿e daring (and yet more knowing than daring) men, who have priz â€¢ your works that now lye upon the hands of your late bookÅ¿ellers widow, but for waÅ¿t paper; which by the way I note as a juÅ¿t retribution of providence, that thoÅ¿e writings which value the Scriptures below the Word of God, Å¿hould themÅ¿elves be valued below the word of man.

You recite an argument which you brought in Sion Coll. viÅ¿ited, Sect. 91. p. 85. to prove that naturall men have eyes to Å¿ee Å¿pirituall things. Naturall men (Å¿ay you) have eyes to Å¿ee becauÅ¿e it is not needleÅ¿Å¿e for Satan to blinde them.
I deny'd your conÅ¿equence, and gave you the ground of that my denyall, viz. becauÅ¿e the Scripture Å¿aith, 1 Cor. 2.14. The naturall man cannot know the things of the Spirit of God.
After your Å¿coffs (which I anÅ¿wer with neglect) you returne thus?

1. You Å¿ay, That by ã€ˆ in non-Latin alphabet ã€‰
the naturall man is not meant the man that is Å¿imply naturall or unregenerate, but Å¿uch a kinde of men wh â€¢ m the ApoÅ¿tle cals carnall, babes in ChriÅ¿t, meaning weake ChriÅ¿tians. Confidently concluding from my producing of this Scripture for this purpoÅ¿e, I underÅ¿tand little of it.
AnÅ¿w. I had rather Å¿uÅ¿pect any interpretation of Scripture, when you Å¿ay 'tis true and Å¿ound, than when you Å¿ay 'tis falÅ¿e and miÅ¿underÅ¿tood.

You have the Å¿treame of godly and learned Interpreters againÅ¿t you. PiÅ¿cator takes this naturall man for a man that Nihil eximium in Å¿e habet prater animam rationalem, qui non eÅ¿t regenitus; a man that hath nothing excellent but a rationall Å¿oule, and is not borne agains, AnÅ¿. Å¿aith, this naturall man is one Qui animalium more verÅ¿atur, qui put at nihil eÅ¿Å¿e p â€¢ Å¿t mortem, one that lives like a brute creature, and thinks there's nothing more after death to be expected. AmbroÅ¿e thus: Animalis homo p â€¢ coribus Å¿imilis, &c.
Ambr. in Lee. SenÅ¿um in terram deprimit, idea
que non â€¢ Å¿Å¿equitur niÅ¿i quae v â€¢ let, ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ put â€¢ t aliquid poÅ¿Å¿e fieri quam quomodo ã€ˆâ—Šã€‰ , ideo quicquaid aliter audit quam norit, Å¿t â€¢ ltum juditar. Theophilact. ã€ˆ in non-Latin alphabet ã€‰ Oecumen ã€ˆ in non-Latin alphabet ã€‰ . This naturall man like the beaÅ¿ts, keeps downe his Å¿ence to the earth, and therefore he only reacheth what be Å¿ees, nor thinketh he that any thing can be, but as he beares; therefore whatever he heares to be otherwiÅ¿e, he judgeth it fooliÅ¿h. Theophilact Å¿aith, This naturall man is one that is given altogether to naturall reaÅ¿onings thinking not that he wants Å¿ â€¢â€¢ our from alove.

Calv. in Loc. Homi â€¢ em onimalem vecat queml. bet hominem Å¿olis naturae facult tibus praelitum in puris natural â€¢ tus relictum. Ter Å¿piritu â€¢ lem intelli â€¢ iur is eujus m â€¢ ns illuminatione Å¿piri â€¢ us Dei regitur.

Calvin Å¿aith, By the Naturall man is meant a man endowed onely
with the faculties of nature, and by the Å¿pirituall, a man whoÅ¿e minde is governed by the illumination of the Sprit.

I Å¿hall make bold to inÅ¿truct my inÅ¿tructor out of IÅ¿idorus PeluÅ¿iota, Ep. l. 5. Ep. 128. ã€ˆ in non-Latin alphabet ã€‰ &c. The Scripture diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿heth (as he Å¿hews) between the ã€ˆ in non-Latin alphabet ã€‰ , the ã€ˆ in non-Latin alphabet ã€‰ . The Carnall, the naturall, and the Å¿pirituall. The Carnall that fall, by reaÅ¿on of their weakneÅ¿Å¿e, into many wayes that are fleÅ¿hly. Naturall, that follow the reaÅ¿oning of the naturall minde and underÅ¿tanding. The Å¿pirituall that are adorned with the gift of the holy GhoÅ¿t, and are illuminated above nature, as (he divinely expreÅ¿Å¿e â€¢ h it) ã€ˆ in non-Latin alphabet ã€‰ , having gotten above naturall reaÅ¿onings.

I Å¿tay in Arminius, DiÅ¿p. 11. TheÅ¿. 8. who Å¿aith, Mens hominis (non renati) in iÅ¿to Å¿tain Caeca eÅ¿t, Å¿alutari Dei, ejuÅ¿
que voluntatis cognitione deÅ¿tituta, non capax illorum, quae Å¿unt Å¿piritus Dei, juxta ApoÅ¿lolum, Animalis homo, &c. The minde of an unregenerate man (Å¿aith he) is blinde and deÅ¿titute of the Å¿aving knowledge of God and of his will, not able to receive the things of the Spirit of God, according to the ApoÅ¿tle, The naturall man, &c. I add, the Å¿ame kind of men are Å¿poken of by Iude,

The ApoÅ¿ile, verÅ¿. 19. he joyning ã€ˆ in non-Latin alphabet ã€‰ , & ã€ˆ in non-Latin alphabet ã€‰ , SeperatiÅ¿ts Å¿enÅ¿uall or naturall, not having the Spirit, together. So James joynes naturall and devilliÅ¿h together, the 3. cap. 15. ver. The wiÅ¿dome that is not from above is Å¿enÅ¿itall or naturall ã€ˆ in non-Latin alphabet ã€‰ , and devilliÅ¿h, Å¿o that the naturall man, 1 Cor. 2.14. is unregenerate.
2. You Å¿ay, That by naturall man, is meant a weake beleever, becauÅ¿e by naturall here, and carnall cap. 3.1.3. are meant the Å¿ame men. Now by carnall there is meant the weak beleever.

AnÅ¿w. Its evident that the carnall man Å¿poken of, cap. 3.1. and the naturall man Å¿poken of in cap. 2.14. are not the Å¿ame. That carnall man was a babe in ChriÅ¿t, and therefore he was Å¿uch an one as had the Spirit of ChriÅ¿t dwelling in him, Rom, 8.9. This naturall man was Å¿uch an one as bad not received the Spirit, ver. 12.14.
3. You endeavour to prove that by carnall man, cap. 3.1. and by naturall man, c. 2.15. are meant the Å¿ame,
BecauÅ¿e the Å¿ame kinde of perÅ¿ons whom he cals Å¿pirituall is oppuÅ¿ed both the naturall man, c. 2.15. and to the carnall, c. 3.1.

AnÅ¿w. Away with this trifling; a man may be oppoÅ¿ed to a
beaÅ¿t and a childe, therefore a beaÅ¿t and a childe are the Å¿ame; dicite Jo. Paean, cop 2.15. the Å¿pirituall and naturall man differ Å¿tatu, as a man that hath the Å¿pirit from him that hath it not; but c. 3.1. the Å¿pirituall man and the carnall differ onely gradu, in degree and meaÅ¿ure of participation of the Å¿ame Å¿pirit, as you your Å¿elf aÅ¿Å¿ert.

4. You Å¿ay, That the ApoÅ¿tle doth not Å¿peake Å¿imply or in generall of the things of God, nor particularly of things Å¿imply neceÅ¿Å¿ary to be beleeved to Å¿alvation, but onely of the deep things of God, which things, v. 6. he had called wiÅ¿dome.
